exercises.title: promiseRace
exercises.description: Implement your own Promise.race — resolve or reject with the first settled promise.
hints: Return a new Promise. Inside, loop over all promises.
Use Promise.resolve(p) to handle non-promise values, then call .then(resolve, reject) for each.
The first promise to call resolve or reject wins — subsequent calls are ignored by the Promise constructor.

exercises.title: promiseAllSettled
exercises.description: Implement your own Promise.allSettled — wait for all promises to settle and return their outcomes.
hints: Return a new Promise that always resolves (never rejects).
Track a count of settled promises. When count equals the array length, resolve with the results array.
Use .then() for fulfilled and .catch() for rejected, then .finally() to increment the counter.

exercises.title: tryCatchWrapper
exercises.description: Write a utility that wraps an async function in try/catch and returns a [error, data] tuple.
hints: Return an async function that uses ...args to forward all arguments.
Inside the returned function, use try/catch around `await asyncFn(...args)`.
On success return [null, result]. On catch return [error, null].

exercises.title: promiseTimeout
exercises.description: Write a function that wraps a promise with a timeout — reject if it takes too long.
hints: Create a second promise that rejects after `ms` milliseconds using setTimeout.
Use Promise.race to race the original promise against the timeout.
The first to settle wins — either the original result or the timeout error.

exercises.title: chainPromises
exercises.description: Write a function that chains an array of async functions sequentially, passing each result to the next.
hints: What does `async/await` do under the hood, and how does error handling work with it?
Array.reduce is perfect here: start with Promise.resolve(initialValue) and .then(fn) for each function.
Key pattern: `fns.reduce((chain, fn) => chain.then(fn), Promise.resolve(initialValue))`

exercises.title: customError
exercises.description: Create custom error classes that extend Error with extra context like status codes and error types.
exercises.instructions:
Create three custom error classes:

**AppError(message, code)**
- Extends `Error`
- Properties: `message`, `code` (number), `name` set to `'AppError'`

**ValidationError(message, field)**
- Extends `AppError` with code `400`
- Additional property: `field` (the invalid field name)
- `name` set to `'ValidationError'`

**NotFoundError(resource)**
- Extends `AppError` with code `404`
- `message` set to `'${resource} not found'`
- `name` set to `'NotFoundError'`

```js
const err = new ValidationError('Invalid email', 'email');
err.message   // 'Invalid email'
err.code      // 400
err.field     // 'email'
err.name      // 'ValidationError'
err instanceof ValidationError // true
err instanceof AppError        // true
err instanceof Error           // true
```
hints: Use `super(message)` to call the parent Error constructor.
Set `this.name` in each constructor to match the class name.
ValidationError calls `super(message, 400)` to pass to AppError, then sets `this.field`.

exercises.title: asyncMap
exercises.description: Write an async version of Array.map that processes items concurrently and returns results in order.
hints: What does `async/await` do under the hood, and how does error handling work with it?
Use array.map() to create an array of promises, then wrap with Promise.all().
One-liner: `return Promise.all(array.map((item, index) => asyncFn(item, index)))`

exercises.title: asyncFilter
exercises.description: Write an async version of Array.filter where the predicate is an async function.
hints: You cannot just use array.filter with an async function — filter does not await.
Map each item to a { item, keep: await predicate(item) } object using Promise.all, then filter synchronously.
Pattern: `Promise.all(array.map(async item => ({ item, keep: await pred(item) })))` then `.filter(r => r.keep).map(r => r.item)`

exercises.title: promiseAny
exercises.description: Implement your own Promise.any — resolve with the first fulfilled promise, or reject if all reject.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function:

**promiseAny(promises)**
- Takes an array of promises
- Returns a new Promise that resolves with the value of the first promise to **fulfill**
- Ignores rejections unless ALL promises reject
- If all reject, reject with an `AggregateError` containing all rejection reasons:
  - `new AggregateError(errors, 'All promises were rejected')`
- If the array is empty, reject with an AggregateError with empty errors array

```js
const result = await promiseAny([
  Promise.reject('a'),
  Promise.resolve('b'),
  Promise.resolve('c')
]);
// result === 'b'  (first to fulfill)
```
hints: This is the opposite of Promise.all: resolve on first success, reject only if all fail.
Track rejection count. When rejectedCount equals the array length, reject with AggregateError.
Use Promise.resolve(p).then(resolve, ...) to handle non-promise values.

exercises.title: errorBoundary
exercises.description: Build an error boundary utility that catches errors from multiple async operations and collects them.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function:

**createErrorBoundary()**
- Returns an object with:
  - `run(asyncFn)` — executes an async function, catches and stores any error, returns `undefined` on failure
  - `get errors` — getter returning array of all caught errors
  - `get hasErrors` — getter returning boolean
  - `get results` — getter returning array of all successful results

```js
const boundary = createErrorBoundary();

await boundary.run(async () => 'ok');
await boundary.run(async () => { throw new Error('fail'); });
await boundary.run(async () => 42);

boundary.results;    // ['ok', 42]
boundary.errors;     // [Error('fail')]
boundary.hasErrors;  // true
```
hints: Use closure to store private `errors` and `results` arrays.
The `run` method should use try/catch — push to results on success, errors on catch.
Use getters (get errors(), get hasErrors(), etc.) for read-only access.

exercises.title: debounceAsync
exercises.description: Write a debounced async function that only executes the latest call after a delay.
hints: Track the timer ID in a closure variable. Clear it on each new call.
Return a new Promise. Inside setTimeout, call fn(...args) and resolve with the result.
Use clearTimeout(timerId) before setting a new timeout to cancel previous calls.

exercises.title: safeJsonParse
exercises.description: Write a safe JSON parser that returns a default value instead of throwing on invalid input.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function:

**safeJsonParse(str, defaultValue)**
- Attempts to parse `str` as JSON
- If successful, returns the parsed value
- If `JSON.parse` throws (invalid JSON), returns `defaultValue`
- If `str` is not a string, returns `defaultValue`
- `defaultValue` defaults to `null` if not provided

```js
safeJsonParse('{"a":1}');          // { a: 1 }
safeJsonParse('invalid', {});       // {}
safeJsonParse('{bad json}', []);    // []
safeJsonParse(undefined);           // null
safeJsonParse('"hello"');           // 'hello'
```
hints: First check if str is a string using typeof.
Wrap JSON.parse in a try/catch block.
Use a default parameter: `defaultValue = null`.

exercises.title: parallelLimit
exercises.description: Run async tasks in parallel but limit how many execute at the same time.
hints: Think of spawning `limit` worker functions that pull from a shared index.
Each worker runs in a while loop: grab the next index, await the task, store the result.
Use Promise.all to wait for all workers to finish.

exercises.title: eventEmitterAsync
exercises.description: Build an EventEmitter that supports async listeners and waits for all of them to complete.
hints: Store listeners in an object: `{ eventName: [fn1, fn2, ...] }`.
emit() should map listeners to promises and use Promise.all.
off() filters the listener array to remove the specific function reference.

exercises.title: promiseFinally
exercises.description: Implement a polyfill for Promise.prototype.finally that runs cleanup regardless of outcome.
hints: Use .then() with both a success and error handler.
In the success handler: run onFinally(), then return the original value.
Key: `Promise.resolve(onFinally()).then(() => value)` preserves value and waits for async cleanup.

exercises.title: retryWithBackoff
exercises.description: Write an async retry utility with exponential backoff between attempts.
hints: Use a for loop from 0 to maxRetries. Try calling fn() each iteration.
Calculate delay: `Math.min(baseDelay * 2 ** attempt, maxDelay)`.
Wait with `await new Promise(r => setTimeout(r, delay))` between retries.

exercises.title: createMiddleware
exercises.description: Build a middleware pipeline where each function can modify data before passing to the next.
hints: Store middleware functions in an array. Track the current index.
The `next` function increments the index and calls the next middleware.
This is similar to how Express.js or Koa middleware works.

exercises.title: Dataset: Weather Station
exercises.description: Analyze weather station data to find temperature extremes, averages, and patterns.
exercises.instructions:
You are given an array of weather readings:

```js
const readings = [
  { station: 'A', date: '2024-01-01', tempC: 5, humidity: 60, wind: 15 },
  { station: 'B', date: '2024-01-01', tempC: -2, humidity: 80, wind: 25 },
  // ...
];
```

Write these functions:

**avgTempByStation(readings)** — returns an object mapping station names to their average temperature (rounded to 1 decimal)

**hottestDay(readings)** — returns the date string with the highest temperature across all stations

**windyDays(readings, threshold)** — returns an array of unique dates where ANY station recorded wind above the threshold

**dailySummary(readings)** — returns an array of `{ date, avgTemp, maxWind }` objects, one per unique date, sorted by date ascending. avgTemp rounded to 1 decimal.

```js
avgTempByStation(readings); // { A: 5.0, B: -2.0 }
hottestDay(readings);        // '2024-01-01'
```
hints: Group readings by station (or date) using an object as a lookup.
For averages: sum values and divide by count, use Math.round(x * 10) / 10 for 1 decimal.
Use Set to collect unique dates for windyDays.

exercises.title: createRateLimiter
exercises.description: Build a rate limiter that queues function calls and executes them at a controlled rate.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function:

**createRateLimiter(maxCalls, windowMs)**
- `maxCalls`: maximum number of calls allowed in the time window
- `windowMs`: time window in milliseconds
- Returns an async function `limiter(fn)` that:
  - Executes `fn()` immediately if under the rate limit
  - Queues and delays execution if the limit has been reached
  - Returns the result of `fn()`
  - Processes queued calls in order

```js
const limiter = createRateLimiter(2, 100); // 2 calls per 100ms

// These two execute immediately:
const r1 = await limiter(() => 'a');
const r2 = await limiter(() => 'b');

// This one waits until the window resets:
const r3 = await limiter(() => 'c');
```
hints: Track timestamps of recent calls. Remove timestamps older than the window.
If under the limit, execute immediately. If at the limit, wait until the oldest call ages out.
Use a queue array with { fn, resolve, reject } objects and process them in order.

exercises.title: Graph: Adjacency List
exercises.description: Implement a graph using an adjacency list with add/remove vertices, edges, and traversal.
hints: Use an object as the adjacency list: `{ vertex: [neighbor1, neighbor2, ...] }`.
Edges are undirected — add to both vertices' neighbor lists.
BFS uses a queue (array with shift) and a Set to track visited vertices.

exercises.title: Proxy Validator
exercises.description: Use JavaScript Proxy to create an object that validates property assignments with custom rules.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function:

**createValidatedObject(schema)**
- `schema` is an object mapping property names to validator functions: `{ propName: (value) => boolean }`
- Returns a Proxy-wrapped object that:
  - On `set`: validates the value using the schema. If the validator returns `false`, throw a `TypeError` with message `'Invalid value for {propName}'`
  - Properties not in the schema can be set freely
  - On `get`: returns the value normally

```js
const user = createValidatedObject({
  age: (v) => typeof v === 'number' && v >= 0 && v <= 150,
  name: (v) => typeof v === 'string' && v.length > 0,
});

user.name = 'Alex';  // ok
user.age = 25;       // ok
user.age = -5;       // throws TypeError: 'Invalid value for age'
user.other = 'free'; // ok (not in schema)
```
hints: Return `new Proxy({}, { set, get })` with custom trap handlers.
In the set trap, check if `schema[prop]` exists and call the validator.
Don't forget to `return true` from the set trap after successful assignment.

exercises.title: asyncReduce
exercises.description: Write an async version of Array.reduce that processes items sequentially with an async reducer.
hints: Use a for loop with await — this ensures sequential execution.
Start with `let acc = initialValue`, then `acc = await asyncReducer(acc, item, i)` each iteration.
Unlike asyncMap, this MUST be sequential since each step depends on the previous result.

exercises.title: Promise Pool: Concurrency Manager
exercises.description: Build a promise pool that manages concurrent async operations with queuing, events, and stats.
exercises.instructions:
Build a class:

**PromisePool(concurrency)**
- `concurrency`: max number of tasks running at once

Methods:
- `add(taskFn)` — adds an async task function to the pool. Returns a Promise that resolves/rejects with the task's result. If under the concurrency limit, starts immediately. Otherwise, queues it.
- `async drain()` — returns a Promise that resolves when all current and queued tasks finish
- `get active` — number of currently running tasks
- `get pending` — number of queued tasks waiting
- `get completed` — total number of finished tasks (success + failure)
- `get failed` — total number of failed tasks

```js
const pool = new PromisePool(2);

pool.add(async () => { await delay(50); return 'a'; });
pool.add(async () => { await delay(30); return 'b'; });
pool.add(async () => { await delay(10); return 'c'; });

pool.active;    // 2 (first two running)
pool.pending;   // 1 (third queued)

await pool.drain();
pool.completed; // 3
pool.active;    // 0
```
hints: Each added task wraps in a Promise. Store { fn, resolve, reject } in a queue.
When a task finishes, check the queue for the next one.
drain() returns a promise that resolves when active === 0 and queue is empty.

exercises.title: Async State Machine: Order + Payment + Shipping
exercises.description: Build an async order processing system with state transitions, validation, and error recovery.
exercises.instructions:
Build three classes that model an async order system.

**Order(id, items)**
- Properties: `id`, `items` (array of { name, price }), `status` (starts `'created'`)
- `get total` — sum of all item prices
- Valid status transitions: created→paid→shipped→delivered
- `async transition(newStatus)` — changes status if valid, throws Error if invalid transition

**Payment(order)**
- `async process()` — simulates payment: if order.total > 0 and order.status is 'created', transitions order to 'paid' and returns `{ success: true, orderId }`. Otherwise throws.
- `async refund()` — only if order.status is 'paid', transitions back to 'created', returns `{ refunded: true }`

**ShippingManager()**
- `async ship(order)` — if order.status is 'paid', transitions to 'shipped', returns `{ shipped: true, trackingId: 'TRK-{order.id}' }`. Otherwise throws.
- `async deliver(order)` — if 'shipped', transitions to 'delivered'. Otherwise throws.
- `get history` — array of `{ orderId, action, timestamp }` for all operations

```js
const order = new Order('001', [{ name: 'Book', price: 15 }]);
const payment = new Payment(order);
await payment.process();   // order.status → 'paid'

const shipping = new ShippingManager();
await shipping.ship(order);    // order.status → 'shipped'
await shipping.deliver(order); // order.status → 'delivered'
```
hints: Order.transition() uses a valid transitions map to check if the new status is allowed.
Payment and ShippingManager check order.status before attempting transitions.
ShippingManager stores history entries with orderId, action, and timestamp.

exercises.title: Async Iterator: Paginated API
exercises.description: Build an async iterator that lazily fetches paginated data one page at a time using for-await-of.
hints: Return an object with [Symbol.asyncIterator] method that returns an async generator.
Use `async *[Symbol.asyncIterator]()` syntax for an async generator.
Use a while loop: fetch a page, yield* the data, check hasMore, increment page.

exercises.title: Error Recovery Pipeline
exercises.description: Build a pipeline that processes data through async steps with per-step error recovery and fallbacks.
hints: Store steps as an array of { name, processFn, fallback, required } objects.
In execute(), loop through steps. Try processFn, then fallback on failure.
Track a 'stopped' flag — when a required step fails, set it to true and mark remaining as 'skipped'.

exercises.title: Circuit Breaker Pattern
exercises.description: Implement the circuit breaker pattern — automatically stop calling a failing service and recover after a cooldown.
exercises.instructions:
Build a class:

**CircuitBreaker(options)**
- `options`: `{ failureThreshold, cooldownMs, successThreshold }`
  - `failureThreshold` (default 3): consecutive failures to open the circuit
  - `cooldownMs` (default 5000): time to wait before trying again
  - `successThreshold` (default 1): consecutive successes needed to fully close

States: `'closed'` (normal), `'open'` (rejecting), `'half-open'` (testing)

- `async call(fn)` — executes fn based on state:
  - **closed**: Call fn. On success, reset failure count. On failure, increment. If failures >= threshold, open circuit.
  - **open**: Throw `Error('Circuit is open')` without calling fn. After cooldownMs, transition to half-open.
  - **half-open**: Call fn. On success, close circuit. On failure, reopen.
- `get state` — current state string
- `get stats` — `{ failures, successes, state }`
- `reset()` — force-close the circuit

```js
const cb = new CircuitBreaker({ failureThreshold: 2, cooldownMs: 100 });
await cb.call(async () => { throw new Error('fail'); }).catch(()=>{});
await cb.call(async () => { throw new Error('fail'); }).catch(()=>{});
cb.state; // 'open'
await cb.call(async () => 'ok'); // throws 'Circuit is open'
```
hints: Track _state, _failures, _successes, and _openedAt timestamp.
In open state, check if cooldown has elapsed. If so, switch to half-open.
In half-open state, a success closes the circuit; a failure reopens it.

exercises.title: Observable Stream: Observer + Subject + Operators
exercises.description: Build a reactive observable stream system with map, filter, and subscribe operators.
exercises.instructions:
Build three classes:

**Observable(subscribeFn)**
- `subscribeFn` receives an observer `{ next, error, complete }` and may return an unsubscribe function
- `subscribe(observer)` — starts the stream, returns `{ unsubscribe }` object
- `map(fn)` — returns a new Observable that transforms each value
- `filter(fn)` — returns a new Observable that only passes values where fn returns true

**Subject**
- Extends or wraps Observable
- `next(value)` — pushes a value to all subscribers
- `error(err)` — sends error to all subscribers
- `complete()` — completes all subscribers
- `subscribe(observer)` — adds a subscriber

**Operators (static methods on Observable):**
- `Observable.fromArray(arr)` — creates Observable that emits each item then completes
- `Observable.interval(ms)` — creates Observable that emits incrementing numbers every `ms` ms

```js
const values = [];
const obs = Observable.fromArray([1, 2, 3, 4]);
obs.filter(x => x % 2 === 0)
   .map(x => x * 10)
   .subscribe({ next: v => values.push(v) });
// values === [20, 40]
```
hints: Observable stores a subscribeFn. subscribe() calls it with the observer.
map() and filter() return NEW Observables that subscribe to the parent and transform values.
Subject maintains an array of observers and pushes values to all of them.

exercises.title: Async Resource Manager: Pool + Lock + Timeout
exercises.description: Build an async resource pool with acquire/release, locking, and timeout support.
exercises.instructions:
Build two classes:

**AsyncLock**
- `async acquire()` — acquires the lock. If already locked, waits in queue.
- `release()` — releases the lock, allowing the next waiting acquirer to proceed
- `get locked` — boolean, whether currently locked

**ResourcePool(factory, size)**
- `factory` is a function that creates a new resource
- `size` is the pool size (creates that many resources upfront)
- `async acquire(timeoutMs)` — gets a free resource. If none available, waits. If timeoutMs provided and exceeded, throws `Error('Acquire timeout')`.
- `release(resource)` — returns a resource to the pool
- `get available` — number of free resources
- `get inUse` — number of checked-out resources

```js
const pool = new ResourcePool(() => ({ id: Math.random() }), 2);

const r1 = await pool.acquire();
const r2 = await pool.acquire();
pool.available; // 0
pool.inUse;     // 2

pool.release(r1);
pool.available; // 1
```
hints: AsyncLock uses a queue of resolve callbacks. If locked, push a new Promise's resolve.
ResourcePool maintains a free list (array) and in-use set. acquire() pops from free or queues.
For timeout: use setTimeout to reject the queued promise if it hasn't been resolved.

exercises.title: Linear Search
exercises.description: Search an array by checking each element one at a time.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `linearSearch(arr, target)` that returns the **index** of `target` in `arr`, or `-1` if not found. You must check each element from left to right.

```js
linearSearch([10, 20, 30, 40], 30) // => 2
linearSearch([10, 20, 30, 40], 50) // => -1
linearSearch([], 1)                // => -1
```

This is an O(n) algorithm — in the worst case you check every element.
hints: How would you look through a list of names on paper to find a specific one?
Use a for loop to iterate through each index. Compare each element to the target.
Loop from i=0 to arr.length-1. If arr[i] === target, return i. After the loop, return -1.

exercises.title: Count Pairs
exercises.description: Count all pairs in an array that sum to a target value.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `countPairs(arr, target)` that returns the number of **unique index pairs** (i, j) where i < j and `arr[i] + arr[j] === target`.

Use a nested loop (brute-force O(n²) approach).

```js
countPairs([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 6)  // => 2  (1+5, 2+4)
countPairs([1, 1, 1], 2)         // => 3  (0+1, 0+2, 1+2)
countPairs([1, 2, 3], 10)        // => 0
```
hints: If you compare every element with every other element, how many comparisons is that?
Use two nested loops: outer loop i from 0 to length-1, inner loop j from i+1 to length-1.
Inside the inner loop, check if arr[i] + arr[j] === target. If so, increment a counter.

exercises.title: Has Duplicates
exercises.description: Check if an array contains any duplicate values using a Set.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `hasDuplicates(arr)` that returns `true` if any value appears more than once, `false` otherwise.

Use a `Set` or object for an O(n) solution — do **not** use nested loops.

```js
hasDuplicates([1, 2, 3, 4])     // => false
hasDuplicates([1, 2, 3, 1])     // => true
hasDuplicates([])               // => false
hasDuplicates(['a', 'b', 'a']) // => true
```
hints: What data structure lets you quickly check if you have seen a value before?
A Set stores unique values. You can check .has() and .add() in O(1) time.
Loop through the array. For each element, check if the Set has it — if yes return true, otherwise add it. After the loop return false.

resources.label: MDN: Set.prototype.has()
resources.description: Check if a value exists in a Set

exercises.title: Two Sum (Optimized)
exercises.description: Find two numbers that sum to a target using a hash map in O(n).
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `twoSum(arr, target)` that returns an array of the **two indices** whose values sum to `target`. Use an object or Map for O(n) lookup.

Return the first valid pair found (scanning left to right). If no pair exists, return `null`.

```js
twoSum([2, 7, 11, 15], 9)  // => [0, 1]  (2+7=9)
twoSum([3, 2, 4], 6)       // => [1, 2]  (2+4=6)
twoSum([1, 2, 3], 10)      // => null
```
hints: For each number, what other number would you need to reach the target?
Store each number's index in an object as you go. Before storing, check if the complement (target - current) already exists.
Create an object `map`. Loop with index i. Let complement = target - arr[i]. If map has complement, return [map[complement], i]. Otherwise set map[arr[i]] = i.

resources.label: MDN: hasOwnProperty
resources.description: Check if object has a property

exercises.title: Binary Search
exercises.description: Implement binary search on a sorted array for O(log n) lookup.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `binarySearch(arr, target)` that returns the **index** of `target` in a **sorted** array, or `-1` if not found.

You must use the binary search algorithm (divide and conquer), not a linear scan.

```js
binarySearch([1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11], 7)   // => 3
binarySearch([1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11], 4)   // => -1
binarySearch([2, 4, 6, 8, 10], 2)      // => 0
binarySearch([2, 4, 6, 8, 10], 10)     // => 4
```
hints: If you open a dictionary to the middle and your word comes after that page, which half do you search next?
Maintain two pointers: left and right. Find the midpoint, compare arr[mid] to target, then narrow the search to the correct half.
While left <= right: mid = Math.floor((left+right)/2). If arr[mid] === target return mid. If arr[mid] < target, left = mid+1. Else right = mid-1.

exercises.title: Frequency Counter
exercises.description: Check if one array is the squared version of another using frequency counting.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `isSquaredVersion(arr1, arr2)` that returns `true` if `arr2` contains the squares of all values in `arr1` (same frequency, any order).

Use a frequency counter approach (O(n)) — do **not** use nested loops or sorting.

```js
isSquaredVersion([1, 2, 3], [1, 4, 9])     // => true
isSquaredVersion([1, 2, 3], [1, 9])         // => false (different lengths)
isSquaredVersion([2, 2, 3], [4, 9, 4])      // => true
isSquaredVersion([2, 2, 3], [4, 9, 9])      // => false (wrong frequency)
```
hints: What if you counted how many times each value appears in both arrays?
Build a frequency map for each array. Then check that for each value in arr1, its square appears the same number of times in arr2.
Create freq1 and freq2 objects. Loop arr1: freq1[val] = (freq1[val]||0)+1. Same for arr2. Then for each key in freq1, check freq2[key*key] === freq1[key].

exercises.title: Sliding Window Max Sum
exercises.description: Find the maximum sum of k consecutive elements using a sliding window.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `maxSubarraySum(arr, k)` that returns the maximum sum of `k` consecutive elements. If `arr.length < k`, return `null`.

Use the sliding window technique (O(n)) — do **not** recalculate the full sum for each window.

```js
maxSubarraySum([1, 2, 5, 2, 8, 1, 5], 2)  // => 10  (2+8)
maxSubarraySum([1, 2, 5, 2, 8, 1, 5], 4)  // => 17  (2+5+2+8)
maxSubarraySum([4, 2, 1, 6], 1)            // => 6
maxSubarraySum([1, 2], 3)                  // => null
```
hints: If you already know the sum of elements 0-3, how can you get the sum of elements 1-4 without adding all four again?
Calculate the first window sum. Then slide: add the next element and subtract the element leaving the window.
Sum first k elements. Then loop from i=k: windowSum += arr[i] - arr[i-k]. Track maxSum throughout.

resources.label: MDN: Math.max()
resources.description: Returns the largest of given numbers

exercises.title: Memoize
exercises.description: Write a generic memoize function that caches results of function calls.
hints: Where could you store previously computed results so the returned function can access them later?
Use a closure! The returned function can access a `cache` object defined in memoize's scope. Use JSON.stringify on arguments as a key.
Create cache = {}. Return function(...args) { const key = JSON.stringify(args); if key in cache return it; otherwise compute, store, and return. }

exercises.title: Write assertEqual
exercises.description: Implement an assertEqual function that throws if two values differ.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `assertEqual(actual, expected, message)` that:
- Does nothing if `actual === expected`
- Throws an `Error` with `message` (or a default message) if they are not equal

```js
assertEqual(1, 1, 'should be 1')        // does nothing
assertEqual(1, 2, 'should be equal')    // throws Error: 'should be equal'
assertEqual('a', 'a')                   // does nothing
assertEqual(true, false)                // throws Error with default message
```
hints: What should happen when actual and expected are NOT the same?
Use the strict equality operator (===) and throw new Error() when they differ.
if (actual !== expected) throw new Error(message || 'Expected ' + expected + ' but got ' + actual);

exercises.title: Write assertArrayEqual
exercises.description: Compare two arrays element-by-element and throw if they differ.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `assertArrayEqual(actual, expected, message)` that:
- Compares two arrays element by element using `===`
- Does nothing if they match (same length, same values in order)
- Throws an `Error` if they differ

```js
assertArrayEqual([1,2,3], [1,2,3])       // does nothing
assertArrayEqual([1,2], [1,2,3])          // throws
assertArrayEqual(['a','b'], ['a','c'])    // throws
```
hints: What two things could make arrays different — their size or their contents?
First check if lengths match. Then loop through each index comparing elements with ===.
Check actual.length !== expected.length first. Then loop: if actual[i] !== expected[i], throw. If loop finishes, arrays match.

exercises.title: Write assertThrows
exercises.description: Implement assertThrows to verify that a callback throws an error.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `assertThrows(fn, message)` that:
- Calls `fn()`
- If `fn` throws, the assertion passes (do nothing)
- If `fn` does NOT throw, throw an Error with `message` or a default

```js
assertThrows(() => { throw new Error('boom'); })  // passes
assertThrows(() => 42)                             // throws!
assertThrows(() => JSON.parse('invalid'))          // passes
```
hints: How can you run a function and detect whether it threw?
Wrap fn() in a try/catch. Use a boolean flag to track if it threw.
Set threw = false. try { fn() } catch(e) { threw = true }. After try/catch, if !threw, throw new Error(message).

exercises.title: Write assertObjectEqual
exercises.description: Deep equality check for flat objects (no nested objects).
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `assertObjectEqual(actual, expected, message)` that compares two **flat** objects (no nested objects/arrays). It should:
- Check that both have the same keys
- Check that all values match with `===`
- Throw an Error if they differ

```js
assertObjectEqual({a:1, b:2}, {a:1, b:2})   // passes
assertObjectEqual({a:1}, {a:1, b:2})         // throws (missing key)
assertObjectEqual({a:1, b:3}, {a:1, b:2})    // throws (value differs)
```
hints: How do you get all the keys from an object?
Use Object.keys() to get arrays of keys from both objects. Check lengths match, then compare each value.
Get keys with Object.keys(). If lengths differ, throw. Loop through expected keys: if actual[key] !== expected[key], throw.

resources.label: MDN: Object.keys()
resources.description: Get an array of object keys

exercises.title: Test a Calculator
exercises.description: Write a test suite for a calculator module that returns pass/fail results.
exercises.instructions:
A calculator object is provided with methods: `add(a,b)`, `subtract(a,b)`, `multiply(a,b)`, `divide(a,b)`.

Write a function `testCalculator(calc)` that returns an array of test result objects:
```js
{ pass: true/false, description: 'string describing the test' }
```

Your tests **must** cover:
- Addition with positive numbers
- Subtraction resulting in negative
- Multiplication by zero
- Division returning a decimal

```js
const calc = { add: (a,b) => a+b, subtract: (a,b) => a-b, multiply: (a,b) => a*b, divide: (a,b) => a/b };
testCalculator(calc)
// => [{pass: true, description: 'adds...'}, ...]
```
hints: What does each calculator method do, and how can you verify the result is correct?
Call each method with known inputs and compare the result to the expected value. Push { pass: result === expected, description } to the array.
results.push({ pass: calc.add(2,3) === 5, description: 'adds 2+3' }). Do similar for subtract (negative result), multiply (by zero), divide (decimal result).

resources.label: MDN: Array.prototype.push()
resources.description: Add elements to end of array

exercises.title: Test Edge Cases
exercises.description: Write tests that cover edge cases for a capitalize function.
exercises.instructions:
A `capitalize(str)` function is provided that should capitalize the first character of a string.

Write `testCapitalize(capitalize)` that returns an array of `{ pass, description }` test results covering these edge cases:
- Empty string input
- Single character
- Already capitalized
- String starting with a number
- `null` or `undefined` input (should not throw)

```js
testCapitalize(str => str ? str[0].toUpperCase() + str.slice(1) : '')
// Should test all the edge cases above
```
hints: What happens when you call a function with unexpected inputs like empty strings, null, or numbers?
Test each edge case: empty string, single char, already capitalized, numeric start, null. For null, wrap in try/catch.
Push a result for each case. For null: let noThrow = true; try { capitalize(null) } catch(e) { noThrow = false }; push { pass: noThrow, ... }.

exercises.title: Spy Function
exercises.description: Implement a createSpy that wraps a function and tracks calls.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `createSpy(fn)` that returns an object with:
- `fn`: a wrapper function that calls the original and records the call
- `calls`: an array of argument arrays (one per call)
- `callCount()`: returns how many times it was called
- `lastArgs()`: returns the arguments of the most recent call, or `undefined` if never called

```js
const spy = createSpy((a, b) => a + b);
spy.fn(1, 2);       // => 3
spy.fn(3, 4);       // => 7
spy.callCount();    // => 2
spy.calls;          // => [[1,2], [3,4]]
spy.lastArgs();     // => [3, 4]
```
hints: How can the wrapper function record each call while still returning the original result?
Use a closure: store a `calls` array. The wrapper pushes its args onto the array, then calls and returns fn(...args).
Return { fn: function(...args) { calls.push(args); return fn(...args); }, calls, callCount: () => calls.length, lastArgs: () => calls[calls.length-1] }.

exercises.title: Mini Test Framework
exercises.description: Build a simple describe/it test runner that collects results.
hints: How can describe() know which tests belong to it if it() is called inside a callback?
Use a currentSuite variable. describe() sets it, calls the callback (which registers tests), then clears it. it() pushes tests onto currentSuite.
Store suites = []. describe(name, cb): create suite object, push to suites, call cb(). it(name, cb): push {name, cb} to current suite. run(): loop suites/tests, try/catch each callback.

exercises.title: Revealing Module Pattern
exercises.description: Create a counter module using closures with public methods.
hints: How can a function remember a variable after it returns?
Declare `let count` inside the function. The returned methods form closures over it.
let count = initial; return { increment() { count++; }, decrement() { count--; }, getCount() { return count; } };

exercises.title: Namespace Object
exercises.description: Organize related math functions into a namespace object.
exercises.instructions:
Create a function `createMathUtils()` that returns an object with these methods:
- `add(a, b)` — returns a + b
- `subtract(a, b)` — returns a - b
- `multiply(a, b)` — returns a * b
- `divide(a, b)` — returns a / b (return `null` if b is 0)

```js
const math = createMathUtils();
math.add(2, 3)       // => 5
math.subtract(10, 4) // => 6
math.multiply(3, 4)  // => 12
math.divide(10, 0)   // => null
```
hints: How do you group related functions together into a single variable?
Return an object where each key is a method name and each value is a function.
return { add(a,b) { return a+b }, subtract(a,b) { return a-b }, ... }; For divide, check if b === 0 first.

exercises.title: Factory Function
exercises.description: Write a factory that creates user objects with private state.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `createUser(name, email)` that returns an object with:
- `getName()` — returns the name
- `getEmail()` — returns the current email
- `setEmail(newEmail)` — updates the email
- `toJSON()` — returns `{ name, email }` object

The `name` and `email` should be **private** — not accessible as properties.

```js
const user = createUser('Alice', 'alice@test.com');
user.getName()   // => 'Alice'
user.getEmail()  // => 'alice@test.com'
user.setEmail('a@new.com');
user.getEmail()  // => 'a@new.com'
user.name        // => undefined (private!)
```
hints: How can you keep data private while still allowing controlled access?
Use closure variables for name and email. Return an object with getter/setter methods that access those variables.
let _email = email; return { getName() { return name; }, getEmail() { return _email; }, setEmail(e) { _email = e; }, toJSON() { return {name, email: _email} } };

exercises.title: Dependency Injection
exercises.description: Write a function that accepts its dependencies as parameters.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `createGreeter(formatter, logger)` where:
- `formatter(name)` — a function that formats a greeting string
- `logger(message)` — a function that logs the message

The returned object has:
- `greet(name)` — calls `formatter(name)` to get the message, then calls `logger(message)`, and returns the message
- `greetAll(names)` — greets each name in the array, returns array of messages

By accepting dependencies, the greeter is testable with any formatter/logger.

```js
const g = createGreeter(n => 'Hello ' + n, msg => console.log(msg));
g.greet('Alice')         // logs and returns 'Hello Alice'
g.greetAll(['A', 'B'])  // returns ['Hello A', 'Hello B']
```
hints: Instead of hardcoding how greetings are formatted, what if someone else provided that function?
The greeter doesn't create its own formatter or logger — it receives them as parameters. Just call formatter(name) and logger(message).
return { greet(name) { const msg = formatter(name); logger(msg); return msg; }, greetAll(names) { return names.map(name => this.greet(name)); } };

exercises.title: Plugin System
exercises.description: Create a system where you can register and execute plugins in order.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `createPluginSystem()` that returns an object with:
- `register(name, fn)` — adds a plugin function with the given name
- `execute(input)` — runs all registered plugins in order, piping the output of each into the next. Returns the final result.
- `list()` — returns an array of registered plugin names
- `remove(name)` — removes a plugin by name

```js
const ps = createPluginSystem();
ps.register('double', x => x * 2);
ps.register('addOne', x => x + 1);
ps.execute(5)   // => 11  (5*2=10, 10+1=11)
ps.list()       // => ['double', 'addOne']
ps.remove('double');
ps.execute(5)   // => 6   (5+1=6)
```
hints: How do you run a series of functions where each one's output feeds into the next?
Store plugins as [{name, fn}]. Execute by reducing: start with input, call each fn in sequence.
Use an array of {name, fn}. execute(input): loop plugins, result = plugin.fn(result). list(): map to names. remove(name): findIndex + splice.

resources.label: MDN: Array.prototype.findIndex()
resources.description: Find index of element matching condition

exercises.title: Service Locator
exercises.description: Build a mini service registry where modules register and look up services.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `createServiceLocator()` that returns an object with:
- `register(name, factory)` — registers a service factory function (called lazily)
- `get(name)` — returns the service instance. Calls the factory **once** on first access, then caches the result.
- `has(name)` — returns `true` if a service is registered
- `getAll()` — returns an object mapping names to their instances (only instantiates those not yet created)

```js
const sl = createServiceLocator();
let created = 0;
sl.register('db', () => { created++; return { query: () => 'data' }; });
sl.has('db')      // => true
sl.get('db')      // => { query: fn }  (created: 1)
sl.get('db')      // same object       (created still 1)
```
hints: How do you delay creating something until it is actually needed, then reuse it?
Store factories separately from instances. On first get(), call the factory and cache the result. On subsequent gets, return the cached instance.
Use two objects: factories and instances. register stores factory. get checks instances first; if missing, calls factory and stores result. has checks factories.

resources.label: MDN: hasOwnProperty
resources.description: Check if object has own property

exercises.title: Mock localStorage
exercises.description: Implement a Storage class with getItem, setItem, removeItem, and clear.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `MockStorage` that mimics the `localStorage` API:
- `setItem(key, value)` — stores a value (convert to string)
- `getItem(key)` — returns the value, or `null` if not found
- `removeItem(key)` — removes the key
- `clear()` — removes all items
- `length` — a getter returning the number of stored items

```js
const s = new MockStorage();
s.setItem('name', 'Alice');
s.getItem('name')    // => 'Alice'
s.length             // => 1
s.setItem('age', 30);
s.getItem('age')     // => '30' (converted to string!)
s.removeItem('name');
s.length             // => 1
s.clear();
s.length             // => 0
```
hints: What simple data structure could you use internally to store key-value pairs?
Use a plain object as the store. Remember that real localStorage converts all values to strings.
Use this._store = {}. setItem: this._store[key] = String(value). getItem: return store[key] or null. length: Object.keys(store).length.

exercises.title: URL Parser
exercises.description: Parse a URL string into its component parts.
hints: What characters separate the different parts of a URL?
Split on '://' to get protocol and the rest. Find '/' to split host from path. Find '?' to separate path from query string.
Use indexOf('://') for protocol. Then indexOf('/') for path start. indexOf('?') for query. Split query on '&' and each pair on '='.

exercises.title: Query String Builder
exercises.description: Convert an object into a URL query string.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `buildQueryString(params)` that converts an object into a query string.

- Prefix with `?`
- Join key-value pairs with `&`
- Handle empty object (return empty string `''`)
- Convert values to strings

```js
buildQueryString({ q: 'hello', page: 2 })        // => '?q=hello&page=2'
buildQueryString({ name: 'Alice' })                // => '?name=Alice'
buildQueryString({})                               // => ''
buildQueryString({ a: 1, b: true, c: 'test' })    // => '?a=1&b=true&c=test'
```
hints: How do you get all the keys from an object and combine them into a string?
Use Object.keys() to get keys, then map each to 'key=value', then join with '&'.
const keys = Object.keys(params); if (!keys.length) return ''; return '?' + keys.map(k => k+'='+params[k]).join('&');

exercises.title: JSON Safe Parse
exercises.description: Wrap JSON.parse to return a default value instead of throwing.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `safeParse(jsonString, defaultValue)` that:
- Tries to parse `jsonString` with `JSON.parse`
- If successful, returns the parsed value
- If it throws (invalid JSON), returns `defaultValue`

```js
safeParse('{"a":1}', {})      // => { a: 1 }
safeParse('invalid', {})       // => {}
safeParse('[1,2,3]', [])       // => [1, 2, 3]
safeParse('', null)            // => null
safeParse('42', 0)             // => 42
```
hints: How can you attempt something that might fail and handle the failure gracefully?
Wrap JSON.parse in a try/catch block. Return the parsed result or the default.
try { return JSON.parse(jsonString); } catch(e) { return defaultValue; }

exercises.title: Event Emitter
exercises.description: Build a simple EventEmitter class with on, off, and emit methods.
hints: How would you store multiple functions for the same event name?
Use an object where keys are event names and values are arrays of callback functions.
this._events = {}. on: push callback to events[event] array. off: filter out the callback. emit: forEach callback, call with args.

exercises.title: Throttle
exercises.description: Implement a throttle function that limits how often a function fires.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `throttle(fn, delay)` that returns a throttled version of `fn`. The throttled function:
- Calls `fn` immediately on the first invocation
- Ignores subsequent calls within the `delay` window (in ms)
- After the delay passes, the next call goes through

Use `Date.now()` for timing (avoid `setTimeout` for testability).

```js
const throttled = throttle(console.log, 1000);
throttled('a')  // logs 'a' immediately
throttled('b')  // ignored (within 1000ms)
// ...after 1000ms...
throttled('c')  // logs 'c'
```
hints: How can you track when the function was last called?
Store the timestamp of the last call in a closure variable. Before calling fn, check if enough time has passed.
let lastCall = 0; return function(...args) { const now = Date.now(); if (now - lastCall >= delay) { lastCall = now; return fn(...args); } };

exercises.title: Simple Router
exercises.description: Build a URL router that maps path patterns to handler functions.
hints: How could you store a mapping from path strings to handler functions?
Use a plain object where keys are paths and values are handler functions.
routes = {}. addRoute: routes[path] = handler. match: if routes[url] exists, call and return it; else return null.

resources.label: MDN: hasOwnProperty
resources.description: Check if object has own property

exercises.title: Request Cache
exercises.description: Build a cache that stores responses by URL with TTL expiration.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `RequestCache` that caches values with a time-to-live (TTL):
- `constructor(defaultTTL)` — sets default TTL in milliseconds
- `set(url, data, ttl?)` — caches data for url. Optional custom ttl overrides default.
- `get(url)` — returns cached data if not expired, otherwise `null`
- `has(url)` — returns `true` if url is cached and not expired
- `clear()` — removes all entries
- `size` — getter returning count of non-expired entries

Use `Date.now()` for timing.

```js
const cache = new RequestCache(1000);
cache.set('/api/users', [{name:'A'}]);
cache.get('/api/users')  // => [{name:'A'}]
cache.has('/api/users')  // => true
// ...after 1000ms...
cache.get('/api/users')  // => null (expired)
```
hints: What information do you need to store alongside each cached value to know when it expires?
Store each entry as { data, expiry: Date.now() + ttl }. On get(), check if Date.now() > expiry.
set: store { data, expiry: Date.now() + (ttl || defaultTTL) }. get: if entry exists and not expired return data, else null. size: count entries where expiry > now.

exercises.title: Accessible Form with Validation Attributes
exercises.description: Build a registration form that uses native HTML5 validation attributes for client-side validation without JavaScript.
exercises.instructions:
Build a registration form with HTML5 validation attributes.

**Required structure:**
- A `<form>` element with `id="registration-form"`
- An email input with `id="email"`, `type="email"`, and `required` attribute
- A password input with `id="password"`, `type="password"`, `required`, and `minlength="8"`
- A username input with `id="username"`, `type="text"`, `required`, and a `pattern` attribute that allows only alphanumeric characters (e.g. `pattern="[a-zA-Z0-9]+"`)
- Each input must have an associated `<label>` using the `for` attribute
- A submit button with text "Register"

**Validation rules via HTML attributes:**
- Email: must be a valid email (handled by `type="email"`)
- Password: required, minimum 8 characters
- Username: required, alphanumeric only (via pattern)

No JavaScript needed — HTML5 validation attributes handle everything.
exercises.starterCode: <!-- Build your registration form with validation attributes -->
exercises.solution:
<form id="registration-form">
  <label for="username">Username</label>
  <input type="text" id="username" name="username" required pattern="[a-zA-Z0-9]+" title="Alphanumeric characters only">

  <label for="email">Email</label>
  <input type="email" id="email" name="email" required>

  <label for="password">Password</label>
  <input type="password" id="password" name="password" required minlength="8">

  <button type="submit">Register</button>
</form>

testCases.description: username uses a pattern attribute for validation

exercises.hint: HTML5 provides built-in validation attributes that work without JavaScript. The browser validates on form submission automatically.
hints: Which HTML attributes let the browser validate user input without writing any JavaScript?

HTML5 provides built-in validation: `required` prevents empty fields, `type="email"` checks email format, `minlength` enforces minimum length, and `pattern` accepts a regex. The browser validates on submit automatically.
Key elements: `<form>`, `<label>`, `<input>`, `<button>`. Important attributes: `type`, `required`, `minlength`, `pattern`, `for`.

exercises.title: Semantic Article Layout
exercises.description: Create a blog post layout using semantic HTML5 elements including article, header, footer, time, figure, and figcaption.
exercises.instructions:
Create a complete blog post using semantic HTML elements. **Required structure:** - An `
` element wrapping the entire post - Inside the article, a `
` containing: - An `

` with the post title - A `` element with a `datetime` attribute (e.g. `datetime="2024-01-15"`) - A `

` with class `author` for the author name - At least one `

` paragraph of post content (outside the header) - A `
exercises.starterCode: <!-- Build your semantic blog post layout -->
exercises.solution:
Understanding Semantic HTML

January 15, 2024

By Jane Developer

Semantic HTML uses elements that describe the meaning of their content, making web pages more accessible and better understood by search engines.

Tags: HTML, Semantics, Accessibility
exercises.hint: Think of an article as a self-contained piece of content that could be syndicated. The header provides metadata, figure wraps media with a caption, and footer closes it out.
hints: What HTML5 elements exist specifically for structuring a self-contained piece of content like a blog post?

An `<article>` wraps the whole post. Inside, `<header>` holds the title/date/author, `<figure>` wraps an image with `<figcaption>`, and `<footer>` holds metadata like tags. The `<time>` element needs a `datetime` attribute for machine readability.
Key elements: `<article>`, `<header>`, `<h1>`, `<time>`, `<figure>`, `<figcaption>`, `<footer>`. Important attributes: `datetime`, `src`, `alt`.

exercises.title: Data Table with Scope and Spanning
exercises.description: Build a multi-section data table with proper accessibility: thead, tbody, th with scope attributes, caption, and column spanning.
exercises.instructions:
Build an accessible quarterly sales data table.

**Required structure:**
- A `<table>` element with `id="sales-table"`
- A `<caption>` element describing the table's purpose
- A `<thead>` with a header row containing at least 4 `<th>` elements, each with `scope="col"`
- At least two `<tbody>` sections (e.g., one for each product category) — each `<tbody>` should start with a `<tr>` that has a `<th>` with `scope="row"` and `colspan` spanning the full table width as a group header
- At least 2 data rows per `<tbody>` with `<td>` elements
- A `<tfoot>` section with a summary/totals row

**Example column headers:** Product, Q1, Q2, Q3

The `scope` attribute on `<th>` tells screen readers whether the heading applies to a column (`scope="col"`) or a row (`scope="row"`). Using multiple `<tbody>` elements groups related rows semantically.
exercises.starterCode:
<!-- Build your accessible data table -->
<!-- Use thead, multiple tbody, tfoot -->
<!-- Add scope and colspan where appropriate -->
exercises.solution:
Quarterly Sales Report 2024
Product Q1 Q2 Q3
Electronics
Laptops $12,000 $15,000 $18,000
Phones $8,000 $9,500 $11,000
Accessories
Cases $2,000 $2,500 $3,000
Chargers $1,500 $1,800 $2,200
Total $23,500 $28,800 $34,200
exercises.hint: Multiple <tbody> elements can group rows into logical sections. Use th[scope="col"] for column headers and th[scope="row"] for row headers. A colspan attribute lets a cell span multiple columns.

resources.label: MDN: th scope attribute
resources.description: Defining header cell scope for accessibility

hints: How can you group related rows in a table, and how does the scope attribute help screen readers understand the table?

Use multiple `<tbody>` elements to group rows semantically. Each group can start with a `<th scope="row" colspan="...">` that spans all columns as a section header. Column headers in `<thead>` use `scope="col"`.
Key elements: `<table>`, `<caption>`, `<thead>`, `<tbody>`, `<tfoot>`, `<th>`, `<td>`. Important attributes: `scope`, `colspan`, `id`.

exercises.title: Flexbox Card Grid
exercises.description: Style a set of cards into a responsive wrapping flex grid where all cards have equal height within each row.
exercises.instructions:
Style the provided cards into a responsive flex grid.

**Requirements:**
1. `.card-grid` uses `display: flex` with `flex-wrap: wrap`
2. `.card-grid` has a `gap` of `16px`
3. Each `.card` should have:
   - A `flex` value that makes it roughly 1/3 width minus gap (use `flex: 1 1 280px` or similar with a min-width)
   - `padding` of `20px`
   - A visible `border` (e.g. `1px solid #334155`)
   - `border-radius` of `8px`
4. Cards should stretch to equal height within each row (default flex behavior with `align-items: stretch`)

The cards should wrap to fewer columns as the container shrinks, without using any media queries.

exercises.providedHtml:

Card 2

This card has more content to show equal height behavior across the row.

Card 3

Card 4

Another card.
exercises.hint: Flexbox with flex-wrap: wrap creates a responsive grid without media queries. The flex shorthand (flex: grow shrink basis) controls how items size and wrap.

resources.label: MDN: flex-wrap
resources.description: Controlling whether flex items wrap to new lines

resources.label: MDN: flex shorthand
resources.description: The flex grow, shrink, and basis shorthand

hints: How does flex-wrap combined with a flex-basis value create a naturally responsive layout?

Set `display: flex` and `flex-wrap: wrap` on the container. Give each card a flex-basis (e.g. `flex: 1 1 280px`) so it has a minimum width but can grow. Cards will automatically wrap to a new row when the container is too narrow.
Container: `display`, `flex-wrap`, `gap`. Cards: `flex`, `padding`, `border`, `border-radius`.

exercises.title: CSS Grid Dashboard
exercises.description: Arrange dashboard panels into a grid layout using CSS Grid with named template areas.
exercises.instructions:
Style the provided dashboard panels into a grid layout using named areas.

**Requirements:**
1. `.dashboard` uses `display: grid`
2. Use `grid-template-areas` to define named regions:
   - Row 1: `"header header"`
   - Row 2: `"sidebar main"`
   - Row 3: `"sidebar footer"`
3. Use `grid-template-columns` with two columns (e.g. `240px 1fr`)
4. Assign each child to its area using `grid-area`:
   - `.panel-header` → `header`
   - `.panel-sidebar` → `sidebar`
   - `.panel-main` → `main`
   - `.panel-footer` → `footer`
5. Add a `gap` of `12px`
6. Each panel should have `padding` of `16px`

The header spans the full width, the sidebar spans two rows on the left.

exercises.providedHtml:
Header
Sidebar
Main Content
Footer
exercises.hint: grid-template-areas takes strings where each string represents a row. Repeat a name to make an element span multiple cells. Then assign each child with grid-area: name.

resources.label: MDN: grid-template-areas
resources.description: Naming grid regions for easy layout

resources.label: MDN: grid-area
resources.description: Assigning an element to a named grid area

hints: How does grid-template-areas let you visually define a layout using strings of named regions?

Define `grid-template-areas` as a series of strings — each string is one row, with space-separated area names. Repeating a name spans that area across cells. Assign each child with `grid-area: areaName`.
Container: `display`, `grid-template-areas`, `grid-template-columns`, `gap`. Children: `grid-area`, `padding`.

exercises.title: Media Query Responsive Nav
exercises.description: Style a navigation bar that switches from a horizontal layout to a vertical stacked layout at a breakpoint using a media query.
exercises.instructions:
Style the provided navigation to be responsive using a media query.

**Desktop layout (default, min-width: 600px):**
1. `.nav` uses `display: flex` with `flex-direction: row`
2. `.nav` has `justify-content: space-between` and `align-items: center`
3. `.nav` has a `background-color` of `#1e293b`
4. Each `.nav-link` has `padding` of `12px 16px`

**Mobile layout (max-width: 599px):**
5. Add a `@media (max-width: 599px)` query that:
   - Changes `.nav` to `flex-direction: column`
   - Sets `align-items: stretch` so links fill the full width
   - Adds a visible bottom border on each `.nav-link` (e.g. `1px solid #334155`)

The nav should be horizontal on wider screens and stack vertically on narrow screens.
exercises.starterCode: /* Style the responsive nav */
exercises.providedHtml: HomeAboutServicesContact
exercises.hint: @media queries let you apply different styles at different screen widths. Changing flex-direction from row to column converts a horizontal layout to vertical.

resources.label: MDN: Using media queries
resources.description: Responsive design with CSS media queries

resources.label: MDN: flex-direction
resources.description: Controlling the direction of flex items

hints: How do you change a layout based on screen width, and which flex property controls horizontal vs vertical stacking?

Start with the desktop layout using `display: flex` and `flex-direction: row`. Then add `@media (max-width: 599px)` to switch to `flex-direction: column` and `align-items: stretch` for the mobile view.
Desktop: `display`, `flex-direction`, `justify-content`, `align-items`. Mobile media query: `flex-direction`, `align-items`, `border-bottom`.

exercises.title: Pricing Cards
exercises.description: Build and style three pricing tier cards displayed side by side, with the middle card highlighted as the popular choice.
exercises.instructions:
Build three pricing tier cards displayed in a row.

**Required HTML:**
- A `.pricing-container` wrapping 3 `.pricing-card` elements
- Each card has:
  - An `<h3>` with the tier name (e.g. "Basic", "Pro", "Enterprise")
  - A `.price` element showing the price
  - A `<ul>` with at least 2 `<li>` feature items
  - A `<button>` with class `btn`
- The middle card should have an additional class `.popular`

**Required CSS:**
1. `.pricing-container` uses `display: flex` with a `gap`
2. Each `.pricing-card` has `padding`, `border-radius`, and a visible `border`
3. `.pricing-card.popular` should be visually distinct — use a different `border-color` (e.g. `#6366f1`) and `transform: scale(1.05)` to make it slightly larger
4. `.btn` has `padding`, a `background-color`, and `border-radius`

The popular card should stand out visually from the other two.

exercises.title: Breadcrumb Navigation
exercises.description: Create and style a breadcrumb navigation with separator arrows generated by CSS pseudo-elements.
exercises.instructions:
Build a breadcrumb navigation with CSS-generated separators.

**Required HTML:**
- A `<nav>` with `aria-label="Breadcrumb"`
- Inside, an `<ol>` with class `breadcrumb`
- At least 3 `<li>` items, each containing an `<a>` link
- The last `<li>` should have class `current` and an `aria-current="page"` attribute on its link

**Required CSS:**
1. `.breadcrumb` uses `display: flex` and `list-style: none`
2. Use a CSS pseudo-element (`.breadcrumb li + li::before`) to insert a separator character (e.g. "/" or "\203A" for a right chevron `›`)
3. The separator should have `padding` or `margin` on both sides
4. `.current a` should be styled differently (e.g. no underline, different color) to show it's the active page
5. Links should have `text-decoration: none`

CSS pseudo-elements generate the separators — no extra HTML needed between items.

/* Style with CSS pseudo-element separators */
exercises.solution:
1. Home
  2. Products
  3. Widget Pro

exercises.hint: The CSS selector `li + li::before` targets every list item that follows another, adding a separator before it. The `content` property inside the ::before pseudo-element inserts the visual separator.

resources.label: MDN: Adjacent sibling combinator
resources.description: The + combinator for targeting next siblings

resources.label: MDN: aria-current
resources.description: Indicating the current item in a set

Use `.breadcrumb li + li::before` with a `content` property to insert a separator (like `\203A` for ›) before every item after the first. This targets adjacent siblings automatically.
HTML: Key elements: `<nav>`, `<ol>`, `<li>`, `<a>`. Important attributes: `aria-label`, `aria-current`. CSS: Key properties: `display`, `list-style`, `content`, `padding`.

exercises.title: CSS Custom Properties Theme
exercises.description: Use CSS custom properties to create a themeable button system with primary and secondary color variants.
exercises.instructions:
Create a theming system using CSS custom properties (variables) to style buttons.

**Requirements:**
1. Define custom properties on `:root`:
   - `--primary`: a primary color (e.g. `#6366f1`)
   - `--primary-hover`: a hover variant (e.g. `#4f46e5`)
   - `--secondary`: a secondary color (e.g. `#10b981`)
   - `--secondary-hover`: its hover variant (e.g. `#059669`)
   - `--radius`: a shared border-radius (e.g. `6px`)
2. Style `.btn` with shared base styles:
   - `padding` of `10px 20px`
   - `border: none`
   - `border-radius` using `var(--radius)`
   - `color: white`
   - `cursor: pointer`
3. `.btn-primary` uses `background-color: var(--primary)`
4. `.btn-primary:hover` uses `var(--primary-hover)`
5. `.btn-secondary` uses `background-color: var(--secondary)`
6. `.btn-secondary:hover` uses `var(--secondary-hover)`

The provided HTML has buttons with both classes. Changing the `:root` variables should update all buttons at once.
exercises.starterCode: /* Define your custom properties and button styles */

testCases.description: uses var() to reference custom properties

exercises.hint: CSS custom properties are defined with --name: value in a selector (usually :root for global scope). Reference them with var(--name). Changing the value in one place updates every usage.

resources.label: MDN: :root pseudo-class
resources.description: The root element selector for global variables

hints: Where should you define CSS variables so they are accessible throughout the entire document?

Define all theme colors as custom properties in `:root` (e.g. `--primary: #6366f1`). Then reference them with `var(--primary)` in your button styles. This centralizes your color palette for easy theming.
Key selectors: `:root`, `.btn`, `.btn-primary`, `.btn-secondary`, `:hover`. Key function: `var(--name)`. Key properties: `background-color`, `border-radius`, `padding`.

exercises.title: Animated Expand/Collapse
exercises.description: Style accordion panels that expand and collapse with smooth CSS transitions using the max-height technique.
exercises.instructions:
Style accordion panels that transition open and closed smoothly.

**Provided HTML** uses checkboxes to toggle panels (CSS-only, no JS).

**Requirements:**
1. `.accordion-item` has a visible `border` and `margin-bottom`
2. `.accordion-header` (the label) has `padding`, `cursor: pointer`, and a `background-color` (e.g. `#1e293b`)
3. `.accordion-body` (the content panel):
   - Default state: `max-height: 0`, `overflow: hidden`
   - Must have a `transition` on max-height (e.g. `transition: max-height 0.3s ease`)
4. When the hidden checkbox is checked, expand the panel:
   - Use the selector `.accordion-toggle:checked + .accordion-header + .accordion-body`
   - Set `max-height` to a large value (e.g. `200px`)
5. Hide the actual checkbox: `.accordion-toggle` should have `display: none`
6. `.accordion-body` content should have `padding` (e.g. `16px`)

The `max-height` transition trick creates smooth expand/collapse animations.
exercises.starterCode: /* Style the animated accordion */
exercises.providedHtml:
Content for section one. This panel expands smoothly.

Content for section two with more text to demonstrate the expand.

Content for the third section.
exercises.hint: The max-height transition trick: set max-height: 0 and overflow: hidden to collapse. When :checked, set max-height to a large value. The transition animates between 0 and the max-height value smoothly.
hints: How can you animate an element's height from 0 to open using CSS only, and what role does the :checked pseudo-class play?

The trick: set `max-height: 0` and `overflow: hidden` to collapse a panel. Add `transition: max-height 0.3s ease`. When the hidden checkbox is `:checked`, use the adjacent sibling selector to set `max-height: 200px` — the transition animates the change.
Key selectors: `.accordion-toggle:checked + .accordion-header + .accordion-body`. Key properties: `max-height`, `overflow`, `transition`, `display: none` (for the checkbox).

exercises.title: Sticky Header with Shadow
exercises.description: Style a page header that sticks to the top of the viewport using position: sticky, with a visible shadow for depth.
exercises.instructions:
Style a header that sticks to the top of the page as the user scrolls.

**Requirements:**
1. `.sticky-header`:
   - `position: sticky`
   - `top: 0` (sticks at the very top)
   - `z-index: 100` (stays above other content)
   - `background-color` of `#0f172a` (solid background so content doesn't show through)
   - A `box-shadow` for depth (e.g. `0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3)`)
   - `padding` of `16px 24px`
2. `.sticky-header` should use `display: flex` with `justify-content: space-between` and `align-items: center`
3. `.content-section` should have `padding` of `24px` to provide scrollable content

The shadow creates a visual separation between the fixed header and scrolling content below.
