exercises.hint: position: sticky makes an element scroll with its container until it reaches the offset (top: 0), then it sticks. A solid background and z-index ensure it covers scrolling content. box-shadow adds visual depth.
hints: What CSS position value makes an element scroll normally until a threshold, then stick in place?

`position: sticky` with `top: 0` pins the header at the top once the user scrolls past it. Add `z-index` so it layers above content, a solid `background-color` so text doesn't bleed through, and `box-shadow` for visual separation.
Key properties: `position`, `top`, `z-index`, `background-color`, `box-shadow`, `display`, `justify-content`, `align-items`.

exercises.title: Login Form with Floating Labels
exercises.description: Build and style a login form where labels float above inputs when focused or filled, using CSS positioning and transitions.
exercises.instructions:
Build a login form with floating label animations.

**Required HTML:**
- A `<form>` with class `login-form`
- Two `.form-group` containers, each with:
  - An `<input>` (one `type="email"`, one `type="password"`) with `id`, `required`, and `placeholder=" "` (a space placeholder — this is the CSS trick)
  - A `<label>` with `for` attribute matching the input id
- A `<button>` with class `submit-btn` and text "Sign In"

**Required CSS:**
1. `.form-group` uses `position: relative` (so labels can be positioned absolutely)
2. `label` is positioned over the input using `position: absolute` with a starting `top` value (e.g. `14px`)
3. `label` has a `transition` on top and font-size
4. When the input is focused or has content, the label moves up:
   - Use `.form-group input:focus + label` and `.form-group input:not(:placeholder-shown) + label`
   - Move label up (e.g. `top: -8px`) and reduce `font-size`
5. Inputs should have visible `border-bottom` and no outline on focus (replace with border color change)
6. `.submit-btn` has `padding`, a `background-color`, and full width (`width: 100%`)

The `placeholder=" "` trick enables `:not(:placeholder-shown)` to detect when the input has content.
exercises.starterCode:
<!-- Build your floating label form -->

/* Style with floating label transitions */

testCases.description: uses CSS transition for floating effect

exercises.hint: The floating label pattern: position labels absolutely over the input. Use placeholder=" " so :not(:placeholder-shown) detects content. On :focus or :not(:placeholder-shown), transition the label's top position upward and shrink its font-size.

resources.label: MDN: :placeholder-shown
resources.description: Detecting when an input shows its placeholder

hints: How can you detect whether an input has content using pure CSS, and how does that help animate a label?

The trick: give inputs `placeholder=" "` (a space). Then `:not(:placeholder-shown)` is true when the user has typed something. Combine with `:focus` to move the absolutely-positioned label upward with a `transition`.
HTML: `<input>` with `placeholder=" "`, `<label>` after input (for `+` selector). CSS: `.form-group input:focus + label`, `.form-group input:not(:placeholder-shown) + label` to move label up.

exercises.title: Responsive Image Gallery
exercises.description: Build and style an image gallery grid that adapts from 1 column on mobile to 3 columns on desktop using CSS Grid and media queries.
exercises.instructions:
Build a responsive image gallery that adapts to different screen sizes. **Required HTML:** - A `.gallery` container - At least 6 `.gallery-item` elements, each containing: - A `
` with class `gallery-img` (as image placeholder with a background color) - A `

` with class `gallery-caption` **Required CSS:** 1. `.gallery` uses `display: grid` 2. Mobile (default): `grid-template-columns: 1fr` (single column) 3. Tablet (`@media (min-width: 600px)`): `grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr)` 4. Desktop (`@media (min-width: 900px)`): `grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr)` 5. `.gallery` has a `gap` of `16px` 6. `.gallery-img` should have `aspect-ratio: 4/3` (or a fixed height) and a `background-color` 7. `.gallery-item` has `border-radius` and `overflow: hidden` The gallery should smoothly adapt from 1 column to 2 to 3 as the viewport widens.
exercises.starterCode:
<!-- Build your responsive gallery -->

/* Style with responsive grid */
exercises.solution:
Mountain Vista

Ocean Sunset

Forest Path

City Lights

Desert Dunes

Snowy Peaks
exercises.hint: Start with a single-column grid (mobile-first). Add @media breakpoints at 600px and 900px to switch to 2 and 3 columns. aspect-ratio on the image placeholder keeps consistent proportions.

resources.label: MDN: aspect-ratio
resources.description: Setting preferred aspect ratios for elements

hints: How does the mobile-first approach work with media queries — should you start with the largest or smallest layout?

Mobile-first: start with `grid-template-columns: 1fr` (single column). Add `@media (min-width: 600px)` for 2 columns and `@media (min-width: 900px)` for 3 columns. Use `aspect-ratio` on image placeholders for consistent sizing.
HTML: `.gallery-item` > `.gallery-img` + `.gallery-caption`. CSS: `display: grid`, `grid-template-columns`, `@media`, `aspect-ratio`, `overflow: hidden`, `border-radius`.

exercises.title: CSS-Only Tabs
exercises.description: Build a fully functional tabbed interface using only HTML radio inputs and CSS — no JavaScript required.
exercises.instructions:
Build a tabbed interface using radio inputs and CSS.

**Required HTML:**
- A `.tabs-container` wrapper
- At least 3 tabs, each consisting of:
  - A hidden `<input type="radio">` with `name="tabs"` (shared name groups them), a unique `id`, and class `tab-radio`. The first should have `checked`
  - A `<label>` with class `tab-label` and `for` matching the radio's id
- A `.tab-panels` container with at least 3 `.tab-panel` elements (one per tab)

**Required CSS:**
1. Hide the radio inputs: `.tab-radio { display: none; }`
2. `.tab-label` styled as clickable tabs: `cursor: pointer`, `padding`, visible bottom border
3. The active tab label must be highlighted. Use the selector:
   `.tab-radio:checked + .tab-label` to apply a different `border-bottom-color` or `color`
4. All `.tab-panel` elements default to `display: none`
5. Show the correct panel when its radio is checked. Use selectors like:
   `#tab1:checked ~ .tab-panels .tab-panel:nth-child(1)` with `display: block`
   (Repeat for each tab)
6. Tab labels should be arranged in a row (use flex on their container)

The key concept: radio inputs + `~` general sibling combinator control which panel is visible.
exercises.starterCode:
<!-- Build your CSS-only tabs -->

/* Style with radio-based tab switching */
exercises.solution:
Overview

Welcome to our product overview. Here you will find everything you need to get started.

Features

Our product includes powerful features for teams of all sizes.

Pricing

Choose a plan that fits your needs. All plans include a 14-day free trial.

testCases.description: at least 3 radio inputs for tabs
hides inactive panels with display: none

exercises.hint: Radio inputs with the same name attribute form a group — only one can be checked at a time. The :checked pseudo-class + the ~ general sibling combinator lets you show/hide panels based on which radio is selected.

resources.label: MDN: General sibling combinator (~)
resources.description: Selecting siblings further in the DOM

resources.label: MDN: :checked pseudo-class
resources.description: Styling based on input checked state

hints: How can radio inputs — which only allow one selection at a time — be used to control which content panel is visible?

Radio inputs with `name="tabs"` form a group where only one is checked at a time. Hide them with `display: none`. Use `:checked + .tab-label` to highlight the active tab, and `#tab1:checked ~ .tab-panels .tab-panel:nth-child(1)` to show the matching panel.

HTML: radio inputs (same `name`), labels (with `for`), tab panels. CSS: `.tab-radio:checked + .tab-label` for active tab style, `#tabN:checked ~ .tab-panels .tab-panel:nth-child(N)` for showing panels.

exercises.title: Full Dashboard with Sidebar and Grid
exercises.description: Build a complete dashboard layout with a collapsible sidebar nav, sticky header, main content grid area, and footer — all responsive from mobile to desktop.
exercises.instructions:
Build a complete, responsive dashboard layout from scratch.

**Required HTML structure:**
- A `.dashboard` wrapper
- A `.dash-sidebar` containing:
  - A `.sidebar-brand` element with text
  - A `<nav>` with at least 4 `<a>` links, one with class `active`
- A `.dash-header` with an `<h1>` title and a `.user-info` element
- A `.dash-main` area containing:
  - At least 3 `.stat-card` elements (e.g. metrics display)
  - A `.content-area` element for primary content
- A `.dash-footer` with footer text

**Required CSS:**
1. `.dashboard` uses CSS Grid with `grid-template-areas`:
   - Mobile (default): single column, all areas stacked vertically
   - Desktop (`min-width: 768px`): sidebar on left column, header/main/footer on right
2. `.dash-sidebar` uses Flexbox with `flex-direction: column`
3. `.dash-header` uses `position: sticky` with `top: 0`
4. `.stat-card` elements use a sub-grid or flex layout to display in a row
5. Use at least 2 CSS custom properties (e.g. `--sidebar-width`, `--accent`)
6. The `.active` nav link should be visually distinct (background or border)
7. All sections have visible borders or backgrounds for visual distinction

This exercise combines Grid, Flexbox, sticky positioning, custom properties, and media queries.
exercises.starterCode:
<!-- Build your full dashboard layout -->

/* Style your responsive dashboard */
exercises.solution:
Dashboard
Overview Analytics Reports Settings

Overview

Welcome, Alex

Revenue

$12,480

Users

1,284

Orders

342

Recent Activity

Dashboard main content area with reports and data visualizations.

Dashboard v1.0 — Built with CSS Grid

testCases.description: sidebar has at least 4 nav links

exercises.hint: This is a composition exercise. Plan the grid areas first: mobile stacks everything vertically, desktop puts sidebar on the left. Use Flexbox inside the sidebar for vertical nav, sticky positioning for the header, and a sub-flex layout for stat cards.

resources.label: MDN: Custom properties
resources.description: CSS variables for theming and reuse

hints: How do you combine CSS Grid for the page layout, Flexbox for component internals, and media queries for responsiveness?

Use `grid-template-areas` for the page layout: mobile stacks vertically, desktop splits sidebar left. Sidebar uses `flex-direction: column` for vertical nav. Header uses `position: sticky`. Stat cards use `display: flex` with `flex-wrap`. Custom properties centralize values like `--sidebar-width`.

HTML: `.dashboard` > `.dash-sidebar`, `.dash-header`, `.dash-main`, `.dash-footer`. CSS: Grid areas, Flexbox, sticky, custom properties, media queries. Key selectors: `.active`, `@media (min-width: 768px)`.

exercises.title: Two-Fer
exercises.description: Create a sentence using a name or a default value.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `twoFer(name)` that returns `"One for [name], one for me."`. If no name is given, use `"you"` as the default.

```js
twoFer("Alice")  // => "One for Alice, one for me."
twoFer("Bob")    // => "One for Bob, one for me."
twoFer()         // => "One for you, one for me."
```
hints: What happens when a function parameter is not provided? What value does it have?
JavaScript supports default parameter values: `function greet(name = "world")`
Use a default parameter `name = "you"` and template literals to build the string.

exercises.title: Resistor Color
exercises.description: Look up the numeric value of a resistor band color.
exercises.instructions:
Resistors have colored bands that encode their resistance value. The first 10 colors map to digits 0-9:

Black=0, Brown=1, Red=2, Orange=3, Yellow=4, Green=5, Blue=6, Violet=7, Grey=8, White=9

Write two functions:
- `colorCode(color)` — returns the numeric value for a color name
- `colors()` — returns an array of all color names in order

```js
colorCode("black")  // => 0
colorCode("red")    // => 2
colorCode("white")  // => 9
colors() // => ["black","brown","red","orange","yellow","green","blue","violet","grey","white"]
```
hints: How can you find the position of an item in an array?
Store the color names in an array in order. The index of each color IS its numeric value.
Use `Array.indexOf(color)` to look up the position. Return a copy of or reference to the colors array from `colors()`.

exercises.title: Resistor Color Duo
exercises.description: Calculate a two-band resistor value from color names.
exercises.instructions:
Each resistor has colored bands. The first two bands form a two-digit number: the first band is the tens digit, the second is the ones digit.

Colors: Black=0, Brown=1, Red=2, Orange=3, Yellow=4, Green=5, Blue=6, Violet=7, Grey=8, White=9

Write a function `decodedValue(colors)` that takes an array of color names and returns the two-digit number from the first two bands.

```js
decodedValue(["brown", "black"])          // => 10
decodedValue(["blue", "grey"])            // => 68
decodedValue(["yellow", "violet", "red"]) // => 47 (ignore extra bands)
```
hints: How do you combine two single digits into a two-digit number?
The first color gives the tens digit and the second gives the ones digit. Multiply the first by 10 and add the second.
Look up each color in the color array to get its index (value), then compute `firstValue * 10 + secondValue`.

exercises.title: Gigasecond
exercises.description: Calculate the moment when someone has lived for 10^9 seconds.
exercises.instructions:
A gigasecond is 10^9 (1,000,000,000) seconds.

Given a number representing a Unix timestamp in seconds, add a gigasecond to it and return the result.

```js
gigasecond(0)           // => 1000000000
gigasecond(1000000000)  // => 2000000000
gigasecond(1234567890)  // => 2234567890
```
hints: What is 10 to the 9th power?
A gigasecond is exactly 1,000,000,000 seconds. You can write this as `1e9` in JavaScript.
Simply add 1e9 (or 1000000000) to the input and return the result.

exercises.title: Raindrops
exercises.description: Convert a number to raindrop sounds based on its factors.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `convert(number)` that converts a number to a string of raindrop sounds:

- If the number has 3 as a factor, add "Pling"
- If the number has 5 as a factor, add "Plang"
- If the number has 7 as a factor, add "Plong"
- If the number does not have 3, 5, or 7 as a factor, return the number as a string

```js
convert(28)  // => "Plong" (divisible by 7)
convert(30)  // => "PlingPlang" (divisible by 3 and 5)
convert(34)  // => "34" (not divisible by 3, 5, or 7)
convert(105) // => "PlingPlangPlong" (divisible by 3, 5, and 7)
```
hints: How do you check if a number is divisible by another number?
Use the modulo operator (%) to check divisibility. Build up a string by appending sounds.
Check `number % 3 === 0`, `number % 5 === 0`, `number % 7 === 0` and concatenate the corresponding sounds. If the result is empty, return the number as a string.

exercises.title: Darts
exercises.description: Calculate the score for a dart landing at given coordinates.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `score(x, y)` that returns the points earned by a dart landing at coordinates (x, y) on a target:

- Outside the target (distance > 10): 0 points
- Outer ring (5 < distance <= 10): 1 point
- Middle ring (1 < distance <= 5): 5 points
- Bullseye (distance <= 1): 10 points

The distance from center is calculated as `sqrt(x² + y²)`.

```js
score(0, 0)    // => 10 (bullseye)
score(0, 5)    // => 5  (middle ring)
score(-9, 0)   // => 1  (outer ring)
score(100, 0)  // => 0  (missed)
```
hints: How do you calculate the distance from a point to the origin?
Use the Pythagorean theorem: distance = Math.sqrt(x*x + y*y). Then check which ring the distance falls into.
Calculate distance, then use if/else: <= 1 gives 10 points, <= 5 gives 5, <= 10 gives 1, otherwise 0.

exercises.title: Space Age
exercises.description: Calculate how old someone is on different planets.
exercises.instructions:
Given an age in seconds, calculate how old someone would be on various planets. An Earth year is 365.25 days (31,557,600 seconds). Each planet's orbital period relative to Earth:

- Mercury: 0.2408467
- Venus: 0.61519726
- Earth: 1.0
- Mars: 1.8808158
- Jupiter: 11.862615
- Saturn: 29.447498
- Uranus: 84.016846
- Neptune: 164.79132

Write a function `age(planet, seconds)` that returns the age rounded to 2 decimal places.

```js
age("earth", 1000000000)   // => 31.69
age("mercury", 2134835688) // => 280.88
```
hints: How many seconds are in one Earth year?
Divide the total seconds by the length of one Earth year to get Earth-years, then divide by the planet's orbital period.
Earth year = 31,557,600 seconds. Planet age = seconds / (earthYear * orbitalPeriod). Round to 2 decimal places with `Math.round(x * 100) / 100`.

exercises.title: RNA Transcription
exercises.description: Transcribe a DNA strand into its RNA complement.
exercises.instructions:
Given a DNA strand, return its RNA complement by replacing each nucleotide:

- G -> C
- C -> G
- T -> A
- A -> U

```js
toRna("G")    // => "C"
toRna("ACGTGGTCTTAA") // => "UGCACCAGAAUU"
toRna("")     // => ""
```
hints: Can you create a mapping from each DNA nucleotide to its RNA complement?
Use an object as a lookup table: `{ G: "C", C: "G", T: "A", A: "U" }`. Then transform each character.
Split the string into characters, map each through the lookup object, and join back together.

exercises.title: Pangram
exercises.description: Determine if a sentence uses every letter of the alphabet.
exercises.instructions:
A pangram is a sentence that uses every letter of the alphabet at least once (e.g., "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog").

Write a function `isPangram(sentence)` that returns `true` if the sentence is a pangram, `false` otherwise. Case should be ignored.

```js
isPangram("The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog") // => true
isPangram("a quick movement of the enemy")              // => false
isPangram("")                                           // => false
```
hints: How many unique letters does the English alphabet have?
If you collect all unique lowercase letters from the sentence, a pangram will have exactly 26.
Convert to lowercase, extract only a-z characters, put them in a Set, and check if the Set size is 26.

exercises.title: Isogram
exercises.description: Determine if a word has no repeating letters.
exercises.instructions:
An isogram is a word with no repeating letters (case-insensitive). Spaces and hyphens are allowed to appear multiple times.

Write a function `isIsogram(word)` that returns `true` if the word is an isogram.

```js
isIsogram("lumberjacks")   // => true
isIsogram("background")    // => true
isIsogram("downstream")    // => true
isIsogram("isograms")      // => false (s appears twice)
isIsogram("eleven")        // => false (e appears three times)
isIsogram("")              // => true
```
hints: How can you check if all characters in a string are unique?
A Set only stores unique values. If the Set of letters has the same size as the total letter count, there are no duplicates.
Extract only letters (ignore spaces/hyphens), lowercase them, and compare Set size to string length.

exercises.title: Hamming Distance
exercises.description: Count the differences between two DNA strands.
exercises.instructions:
The Hamming distance between two strings of equal length is the number of positions where the corresponding characters are different.

Write a function `compute(strand1, strand2)` that returns the Hamming distance. If the strands have different lengths, throw an Error.

```js
compute("GAGCCTACTAACGGGAT", "CATCGTAATGACGGCCT") // => 7
compute("GGACG", "GGTCG")                         // => 1
compute("", "")                                    // => 0
```
hints: How do you compare two strings character by character?
Loop through both strings simultaneously and count positions where characters differ.
First check that lengths match (throw Error if not). Then loop with a counter, incrementing when `strand1[i] !== strand2[i]`.

exercises.title: Collatz Conjecture
exercises.description: Count the steps to reach 1 using the Collatz sequence.
exercises.instructions:
The Collatz Conjecture states that for any positive integer n:
- If n is even, divide it by 2
- If n is odd, multiply by 3 and add 1

Repeating this process will always eventually reach 1.

Write a function `steps(n)` that returns how many steps it takes to reach 1. Throw an Error for non-positive numbers.

```js
steps(1)   // => 0
steps(16)  // => 4 (16 -> 8 -> 4 -> 2 -> 1)
steps(12)  // => 9
```
hints: What are the two possible operations at each step?
Use a while loop that runs until n equals 1. At each step, check if n is even or odd and apply the corresponding rule.
Count steps with a counter variable. While n !== 1: if even, n = n/2; if odd, n = 3*n + 1. Increment counter each iteration.

exercises.title: Triangle
exercises.description: Determine if a triangle is equilateral, isosceles, or scalene.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `triangle(a, b, c)` that returns what kind of triangle is formed by three sides:

- **"equilateral"**: all three sides are equal
- **"isosceles"**: exactly two sides are equal
- **"scalene"**: no sides are equal
- **"invalid"**: sides cannot form a triangle (any side is 0, or any side is >= sum of other two)

```js
triangle(2, 2, 2) // => "equilateral"
triangle(3, 4, 4) // => "isosceles"
triangle(3, 4, 5) // => "scalene"
triangle(0, 0, 0) // => "invalid"
triangle(1, 1, 3) // => "invalid"
```
hints: What conditions must three sides satisfy to form a valid triangle?
First validate: all sides must be positive, and each side must be less than the sum of the other two. Then classify.
Check validity first (sides > 0 and triangle inequality). Then: all equal = equilateral, any two equal = isosceles, otherwise scalene.

exercises.title: Difference of Squares
exercises.description: Find the difference between the square of the sum and the sum of the squares.
exercises.instructions:
Given a natural number n, compute:

- **Square of the sum**: (1 + 2 + ... + n)²
- **Sum of the squares**: 1² + 2² + ... + n²
- **Difference**: square of the sum minus sum of the squares

Write three functions: `squareOfSum(n)`, `sumOfSquares(n)`, and `differenceOfSquares(n)`.

```js
squareOfSum(10)         // => 3025
sumOfSquares(10)        // => 385
differenceOfSquares(10) // => 2640
```
hints: Can you compute the sum 1+2+...+n without a loop?
The sum of 1 to n is `n*(n+1)/2`. You can square that result. For sum of squares, loop and add i*i.
squareOfSum: use the formula n*(n+1)/2, then square it. sumOfSquares: loop from 1 to n adding i*i. difference: subtract one from the other.

exercises.title: ETL
exercises.description: Transform data from one format to another.
hints: How do you iterate over an object's key-value pairs?
Use Object.entries() to get [score, letters] pairs. Then loop through each letter array.
For each [score, letters] pair, loop through letters and set result[letter.toLowerCase()] = Number(score).

exercises.title: Armstrong Numbers
exercises.description: Determine if a number is an Armstrong number.
exercises.instructions:
An Armstrong number is a number that equals the sum of its own digits each raised to the power of the number of digits.

For example:
- 9 is Armstrong: 9¹ = 9
- 153 is Armstrong: 1³ + 5³ + 3³ = 1 + 125 + 27 = 153
- 154 is NOT Armstrong: 1³ + 5³ + 4³ = 1 + 125 + 64 = 190

Write a function `isArmstrong(n)` that returns `true` if n is an Armstrong number.

```js
isArmstrong(9)   // => true
isArmstrong(153) // => true
isArmstrong(154) // => false
```
hints: How many digits does the number have? How do you extract individual digits?
Convert to string to get digit count and individual digits. Raise each digit to the power of the total digit count.
Split the number into digits, raise each to the power of the digit count, sum them up, and compare to the original number.

exercises.title: Bob
exercises.description: Respond differently based on what is said to Bob.
exercises.instructions:
Bob is a lackadaisical teenager. He responds to messages according to these rules:

- **"Whoa, chill out!"** if you YELL at him (all caps, with at least one letter)
- **"Sure."** if you ask him a question (ends with "?")
- **"Calm down, I know what I'm doing!"** if you yell a question at him
- **"Fine. Be that way!"** if you say nothing (empty or whitespace only)
- **"Whatever."** for everything else

Note: Yelling a question takes priority — check for that first.

```js
bob("WATCH OUT!")        // => "Whoa, chill out!"
bob("Does this work?")   // => "Sure."
bob("WHAT?!")            // => "Calm down, I know what I'm doing!"
bob("   ")               // => "Fine. Be that way!"
bob("Hello there")       // => "Whatever."
```
hints: What are the different conditions you need to check? In what order should you check them?
Determine if the message is empty, a question (ends with ?), or yelling (all uppercase with at least one letter). Check yelling-question first since it combines two conditions.

Trim the message. Check empty first. Then determine isQuestion (endsWith "?") and isYelling (has letters AND equals its uppercase version). Check yelling+question, then yelling, then question, then default.

exercises.title: Nucleotide Count
exercises.description: Count occurrences of each nucleotide in a DNA strand.
exercises.instructions:
Given a DNA strand, count how many times each nucleotide (A, C, G, T) appears.

Write a function `nucleotideCounts(strand)` that returns an object with counts.

Throw an Error if the strand contains invalid characters.

```js
nucleotideCounts("")          // => { A: 0, C: 0, G: 0, T: 0 }
nucleotideCounts("GATTACA")   // => { A: 3, C: 1, G: 1, T: 2 }
```
hints: How do you count occurrences of specific characters in a string?
Start with an object { A: 0, C: 0, G: 0, T: 0 } and increment as you iterate through the string.
Loop through each character. If it's a valid nucleotide, increment its count. If not, throw an Error.

exercises.title: Run-Length Encoding
exercises.description: Encode and decode strings using run-length encoding.
exercises.instructions:
Run-length encoding compresses consecutive identical characters by storing the count and the character.

Write two functions:
- `encode(str)` — compress the string (omit count of 1)
- `decode(str)` — decompress back to original

```js
encode("AABCCCDEEEE") // => "2AB3CD4E"
encode("WWWWWWWWWWWW") // => "12W"
encode("A")           // => "A"
decode("2AB3CD4E")    // => "AABCCCDEEEE"
decode("12W")         // => "WWWWWWWWWWWW"
```
hints: For encoding: how do you identify runs of consecutive identical characters?
For encoding, you can use regex `/(.)\1*/g` to match runs. For decoding, match `/(\d+)(.)/g` to find count+char pairs.
Encode: replace each run with count (omit if 1) + character. Decode: replace each count+char pair with char repeated count times.

exercises.title: Series
exercises.description: Extract all contiguous substrings of a given length.
exercises.instructions:
Given a string of digits and a length, return all contiguous substrings of that length.

Throw an Error if the requested length is larger than the string or is zero/negative.

```js
series("01234", 1) // => ["0","1","2","3","4"]
series("01234", 2) // => ["01","12","23","34"]
series("01234", 5) // => ["01234"]
```
hints: How would you extract all overlapping windows of a given size from a string?
Use a sliding window: start at index 0 and slide forward, taking a substring of the desired length at each position.
Loop from i = 0 to digits.length - length. At each position, slice out a substring of the given length and add it to the result array.

exercises.title: Roman Numerals
exercises.description: Convert a number to its Roman numeral representation.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `toRoman(number)` that converts a positive integer to a Roman numeral string.

Roman numerals use subtractive notation for 4, 9, 40, 90, 400, and 900.

```js
toRoman(1) // => "I"
toRoman(4) // => "IV"
toRoman(1990) // => "MCMXC"
toRoman(2024) // => "MMXXIV"
```
hints: Can you build the result by repeatedly subtracting the largest possible Roman value?
Create a lookup table of values and numerals in descending order, including subtractive pairs like 900, 400, 90, 40, 9, and 4.
Loop through the lookup table. While the number is >= the current value, append the numeral and subtract the value.

exercises.title: Matching Brackets
exercises.description: Check if brackets, braces, and parentheses are properly matched and nested.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `isPaired(input)` that returns `true` if all brackets are correctly matched and nested, `false` otherwise.

Only `()`, `[]`, and `{}` matter. Other characters should be ignored.

```js
isPaired("()") // => true
isPaired("([{}])") // => true
isPaired("([)") // => false
isPaired("{what is (4 + 5) * 2}") // => true
```
hints: What data structure lets you match the most recent opening bracket with the current closing bracket?
Use a stack: push opening brackets and pop when you see a closing bracket. Check that the popped bracket matches.
Loop through each character. Push openers onto a stack. For closers, pop the stack and verify it matches. At the end, the stack should be empty.

exercises.title: Luhn Algorithm
exercises.description: Validate a number string using the Luhn algorithm.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `valid(input)` that checks if a string is valid per the Luhn algorithm.

Rules:
- Strip spaces; reject if any non-digit remains or length < 2
- Starting from the rightmost digit, double every second digit
- If doubling produces a value > 9, subtract 9
- Sum all digits; valid if sum % 10 === 0

```js
valid("4539 3195 0343 6467") // => true
valid("8273 1232 7352 0569") // => false
valid("059a") // => false
valid("0") // => false
```
hints: How do you process digits from right to left and apply different logic to every other digit?
Strip spaces, reject non-digits, then iterate from the right. Double every second digit and subtract 9 if the result exceeds 9.
After processing, sum all digits. The number is valid if the total is divisible by 10.

exercises.title: Scrabble Score
exercises.description: Calculate the Scrabble score for a given word.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `score(word)` that calculates the Scrabble score.

Letter values:
- 1: A, E, I, O, U, L, N, R, S, T
- 2: D, G
- 3: B, C, M, P
- 4: F, H, V, W, Y
- 5: K
- 8: J, X
- 10: Q, Z

```js
score("cabbage") // => 14
score("") // => 0
score("quirky") // => 22
```
hints: How can you map each letter to its point value and sum them up?
Create an object mapping each uppercase letter to its score. Convert the word to uppercase and look up each letter.
Use split and reduce to sum up the score for each character in the word.

resources.label: MDN: Array.prototype.reduce()
resources.description: Reduce an array to a single value

exercises.title: Pig Latin
exercises.description: Translate a sentence into Pig Latin.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `translate(sentence)` that converts English to Pig Latin.

Rules:
1. Words starting with a vowel sound (a, e, i, o, u) or "xr"/"yt": add "ay" to the end
2. Words starting with consonant(s): move consonant cluster to end, then add "ay"
3. If "qu" appears in the consonant cluster, move both to end (e.g., "square" -> "aresqu" + "ay")

```js
translate("apple") // => "appleay"
translate("chair") // => "airchay"
translate("square") // => "aresquay"
translate("yellow") // => "ellowyay"
```
hints: How do you identify whether a word starts with a vowel sound vs. a consonant cluster?
Check for vowel-start words first (including xr, yt). Otherwise, match the leading consonant cluster (including qu if present).
Use a regex like /^([^aeiou]*qu|[^aeiou]+)/ to capture the consonant prefix, then move it to the end and add "ay".

resources.label: MDN: String.prototype.match()
resources.description: Match a string against a regex

exercises.title: Pascal's Triangle
exercises.description: Generate the specified number of rows of Pascal's Triangle.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `rows(count)` that returns the first `count` rows of Pascal's Triangle.

Each row starts and ends with 1. Interior values are the sum of the two values above.

```js
rows(1) // => [[1]]
rows(4) // => [[1],[1,1],[1,2,1],[1,3,3,1]]
```
hints: How does each row relate to the row above it?
Each interior element is the sum of the two elements directly above it. Start and end each row with 1.
Build each row by iterating: row[j] = previousRow[j-1] + previousRow[j] for interior positions.

exercises.title: Sieve of Eratosthenes
exercises.description: Find all prime numbers up to a given limit using the Sieve of Eratosthenes.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `primes(limit)` that returns an array of all primes up to and including `limit`.

Use the Sieve of Eratosthenes algorithm: mark composites by iterating through multiples.

```js
primes(10) // => [2, 3, 5, 7]
primes(1)  // => []
```
hints: How does the Sieve of Eratosthenes eliminate composite numbers?
Create a boolean array. For each prime found, mark all its multiples as composite starting from its square.
Initialize an array of true values. For each index i starting at 2, if it is still true, mark all multiples i*i, i*i+i, ... as false. Collect the true indices.

exercises.title: Grade School
exercises.description: Manage a school roster: add students to grades and retrieve sorted rosters.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `GradeSchool` with the following methods:

- `add(name, grade)` - add a student to a grade
- `grade(gradeNum)` - return sorted list of students in that grade
- `roster()` - return an object with grade keys and sorted student arrays

Students within a grade should be sorted alphabetically. If a student is added to a new grade, remove them from the old one.

```js
const school = new GradeSchool();
school.add("Jim", 2);
school.add("Anna", 2);
school.grade(2) // => ["Anna", "Jim"]
```
hints: How would you store students organized by grade and keep them sorted?
Use an object with grade numbers as keys and sorted arrays as values. When adding, remove the student from any existing grade first.
In add(), filter the student from all grades, then push to the new grade and sort. Return copies from grade() and roster() to prevent mutation.

exercises.title: Allergies
exercises.description: Determine allergies from a score using bitwise operations.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `Allergies` that takes a score and provides:

- `list()` - returns array of allergen names the person is allergic to
- `allergicTo(item)` - returns true if allergic to that item

Allergen scores (powers of 2):
- eggs: 1, peanuts: 2, shellfish: 4, strawberries: 8
- tomatoes: 16, chocolate: 32, pollen: 64, cats: 128

```js
const a = new Allergies(34);
a.list()           // => ["peanuts", "chocolate"]
a.allergicTo("peanuts") // => true
a.allergicTo("eggs")   // => false
```
hints: How can bitwise AND help determine if a specific bit is set in the score?
Each allergen maps to a power of 2. Use score & (1 << index) to check if that bit is set.
Store allergens in order by their bit position. Filter the list using bitwise AND to find active allergies.

exercises.title: Secret Handshake
exercises.description: Convert a number to a sequence of actions using binary representation.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `commands(number)` that converts a number (1-31) to a secret handshake sequence.

Bit meanings:
- 1 (00001): "wink"
- 2 (00010): "double blink"
- 4 (00100): "close your eyes"
- 8 (01000): "jump"
- 16 (10000): reverse the order

```js
commands(9)  // => ["wink", "jump"]
commands(19) // => ["jump", "wink"] (reversed)
```
hints: How do you test individual bits of a number to determine which actions apply?
Use bitwise AND with each power of 2 to check which actions are active. Check bit 16 to decide if the result should be reversed.
Filter actions by checking number & (1 << i). If number & 16 is set, reverse the result before returning.

exercises.title: Clock
exercises.description: Represent time without dates, supporting add/subtract minutes and equality.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `Clock` that represents time as hours and minutes (no date).

- `new Clock(hour, minute)` - handles overflow/underflow (e.g., 25:00 -> 01:00, -1:00 -> 23:00)
- `toString()` - returns "HH:MM" format
- `plus(minutes)` - returns a new Clock with added minutes
- `minus(minutes)` - returns a new Clock with subtracted minutes
- `equals(other)` - returns true if same time

```js
new Clock(25, 0).toString()  // => "01:00"
new Clock(10, 0).plus(3).toString()  // => "10:03"
```
hints: How can you normalize hours and minutes to always stay within 0-23 and 0-59?
Convert everything to total minutes, use modulo 1440 (24*60), and handle negative values by adding 1440.
In the constructor, compute totalMinutes = hour*60 + minute, mod 1440. If negative, add 1440. Extract hours and minutes from the normalized total.

resources.label: MDN: String.prototype.padStart()

exercises.title: Robot Name
exercises.description: Generate unique robot names in the format XX### (2 letters + 3 digits).
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `Robot` where each instance gets a unique name in the format of two uppercase letters followed by three digits (e.g., "AB123").

- `name` - property that returns the robot name
- `reset()` - generates a new unique name

All names must be unique across all Robot instances.

```js
const r = new Robot();
r.name // => e.g. "RX837"
r.reset();
r.name // => a new name like "AB123"
```
hints: How do you ensure every robot name is unique, even after resets?
Use a static Set to track all used names. Generate random names until you find one not in the set.
Use String.fromCharCode(65 + random) for letters and padStart for digits. Store used names in a class-level Set.

resources.label: MDN: Set
resources.description: Set data structure for unique values

exercises.title: Strain
exercises.description: Implement keep and discard operations without using built-in filter.
exercises.instructions:
Write two functions:

- `keep(collection, predicate)` - returns elements where predicate returns true
- `discard(collection, predicate)` - returns elements where predicate returns false

Do NOT use `Array.prototype.filter`.

```js
keep([1, 2, 3, 4], x => x % 2 === 0) // => [2, 4]
discard([1, 2, 3, 4], x => x % 2 === 0) // => [1, 3]
```
hints: How would you implement filtering without using the built-in filter method?
Use a for loop to iterate and push matching elements into a new array. Discard is the inverse of keep.
For keep, loop through and push items where predicate(item) is true. For discard, call keep with a negated predicate.

exercises.title: Perfect Numbers
exercises.description: Classify numbers as perfect, abundant, or deficient based on their aliquot sum.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `classify(number)` that determines if a number is perfect, abundant, or deficient.

The aliquot sum is the sum of all proper divisors (excluding the number itself).

- Perfect: aliquot sum equals the number (e.g., 6 = 1+2+3)
- Abundant: aliquot sum is greater than the number
- Deficient: aliquot sum is less than the number

Throw an error for numbers less than 1.

```js
classify(6)  // => "perfect"
classify(12) // => "abundant"
classify(7)  // => "deficient"
```
hints: How do you find all proper divisors of a number?
Loop from 1 to number/2 and collect divisors where number % i === 0. Sum them up.
Compare the sum of divisors to the original number: equal means perfect, greater means abundant, less means deficient.

exercises.title: Sum of Multiples
exercises.description: Find the sum of all unique multiples of given factors below a limit.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `sum(factors, limit)` that returns the sum of all unique multiples of the given factors that are less than the limit.

```js
sum([3, 5], 20)  // => 78 (3+5+6+9+10+12+15+18)
sum([7, 13], 10) // => 7
sum([], 10)      // => 0
```
hints: How do you collect all multiples of several factors while avoiding duplicates?
Use a Set to store multiples. For each factor, generate its multiples below the limit.
Loop through each factor, add all its multiples below the limit to a Set (for uniqueness), then sum the Set values.

exercises.title: All Your Base
exercises.description: Convert a number from one base to another.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `convert(digits, inputBase, outputBase)` that converts a number represented as an array of digits in `inputBase` to an array of digits in `outputBase`.

Throw an error for invalid inputs (base < 2, invalid digits, empty input).

```js
convert([1, 0], 2, 10)   // => [2]     (binary 10 = decimal 2)
convert([1, 0, 1], 2, 8) // => [5]     (binary 101 = octal 5)
convert([7], 10, 2)      // => [1, 1, 1] (decimal 7 = binary 111)
```
hints: How do you convert between arbitrary bases?
First convert the input digits to a base-10 integer, then convert that integer to the output base.
Use reduce to compute the decimal value: acc * inputBase + digit. Then repeatedly divide by outputBase, collecting remainders.

resources.label: MDN: Array.prototype.unshift()

exercises.title: Rotational Cipher
exercises.description: Rotate letters by N positions in the alphabet.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `rotate(text, shift)` that applies a rotational cipher (like ROT13 but with a configurable shift).

Only rotate letters. Preserve case and leave non-letter characters unchanged.

```js
rotate("a", 1)       // => "b"
rotate("OMG", 5)     // => "TRL"
rotate("a1b2", 13)   // => "n1o2"
```
hints: How do you shift a letter by N positions while wrapping around the alphabet?
Use charCodeAt to get the character code, add the shift with modulo 26 to wrap around, then convert back.
For each letter, subtract the base (65 for uppercase, 97 for lowercase), add shift, mod 26, add base back. Use String.fromCharCode.

exercises.title: Atbash Cipher
exercises.description: Encode and decode text using the Atbash cipher (a=z, b=y, c=x, ...).
exercises.instructions:
Write two functions:

- `encode(text)` - encode plain text to Atbash cipher, grouped in 5-letter chunks
- `decode(text)` - decode Atbash cipher back to plain text

The Atbash cipher maps a->z, b->y, c->x, etc. Only letters and digits are kept. Letters are lowercased.

```js
encode("test")     // => "gvhg"
encode("Testing 1 2 3") // => "gvhgr mt123"
decode("gvhg")     // => "test"
```
hints: How does the Atbash cipher relate each letter to its mirror in the alphabet?
a (97) maps to z (122), b (98) maps to y (121). The formula is: 219 - charCode. Only transform letters.
For encoding: lowercase, strip non-alphanumeric, apply the cipher, then group into 5-character chunks. For decoding: strip spaces, apply the same cipher.

exercises.title: Diamond
exercises.description: Generate a diamond shape from a given letter.
hints: How do you compute the spacing for each row of the diamond?
The width is 2*n - 1 where n is the letter position. Row i has the letter at positions (n-1-i) and (n-1+i).
Build the top half including the middle, then mirror it (excluding the middle row) for the bottom half.

exercises.title: Bowling
exercises.description: Score a complete bowling game with strikes, spares, and 10th frame bonuses.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `Bowling` with:

- `roll(pins)` - record a roll (0-10 pins)
- `score()` - return the total score after the game is complete

Rules:
- 10 frames. A strike (10 on first roll) adds next 2 rolls as bonus.
- A spare (10 total in a frame) adds next 1 roll as bonus.
- 10th frame: if strike or spare, get fill balls (up to 3 rolls total in frame 10).

```js
const game = new Bowling();
// Perfect game: 12 strikes = 300
```
hints: How do strikes and spares affect scoring differently from regular frames?
Walk through rolls frame-by-frame. A strike uses one roll plus the next two as bonus. A spare uses two rolls plus the next one as bonus.
Use a roll index that advances by 1 for strikes and 2 for non-strikes. Add bonus rolls from future positions in the array.

exercises.title: Simple Linked List
exercises.description: Implement a singly linked list with push, pop, size, and toArray.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `LinkedList` with:

- `push(value)` - add value to the head of the list
- `pop()` - remove and return the value at the head
- `size()` - return the number of elements
- `toArray()` - return elements as an array (head first)
- `reverse()` - reverse the list in place

```js
const list = new LinkedList();
list.push(1);
list.push(2);
list.toArray() // => [2, 1]
list.pop()     // => 2
```
hints: What does a singly linked list node look like, and how do you add to the front?
Each node has a value and a next pointer. Push creates a new head pointing to the old head.
For reverse: walk the list, changing each next pointer to the previous node. Track prev, current, and next.

exercises.title: Custom Set
exercises.description: Implement a custom set with union, intersection, difference, subset, and disjoint.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `CustomSet` that takes an optional array of initial values:

- `contains(value)` - true if value is in set
- `add(value)` - add value, return this
- `empty()` - true if set is empty
- `size()` - number of elements
- `isSubset(other)` - true if this is a subset of other
- `isDisjoint(other)` - true if no common elements
- `isEqual(other)` - true if same elements
- `union(other)` - returns new set with all elements from both
- `intersection(other)` - returns new set with common elements
- `difference(other)` - returns new set with elements in this but not other

```js
new CustomSet([1, 2]).union(new CustomSet([2, 3]))
// => CustomSet with [1, 2, 3]
```
hints: How do you implement set operations like union and intersection using arrays?
Use an internal array and check for duplicates on add. Union combines both, intersection filters to common elements.
For subset, check every element of this is in other. For disjoint, check no element of this is in other. Union adds all from both, deduped.

exercises.title: Binary Search Tree
exercises.description: Implement a BST with insert and in-order, pre-order, post-order traversals.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `BinarySearchTree` with:

- `constructor(value)` - creates a node with that value
- `insert(value)` - inserts a value (<=  goes left, > goes right)
- `inOrder()` - returns in-order traversal array
- `preOrder()` - returns pre-order traversal array
- `postOrder()` - returns post-order traversal array

```js
const tree = new BinarySearchTree(4);
tree.insert(2); tree.insert(6); tree.insert(1);
tree.inOrder() // => [1, 2, 4, 6]
```
hints: How does a binary search tree decide where to place a new value?
Values <= current go left, > go right. Recursively insert into the appropriate subtree.
For in-order: visit left, then root, then right. For pre-order: root, left, right. For post-order: left, right, root.

exercises.title: Circular Buffer
exercises.description: Implement a fixed-size circular buffer with read, write, and overwrite.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `CircularBuffer` with:

- `constructor(capacity)` - creates a buffer of the given size
- `read()` - read and remove the oldest value; throw if empty
- `write(value)` - write a value; throw if full
- `overwrite(value)` - write a value, overwriting the oldest if full
- `clear()` - empty the buffer

```js
const buf = new CircularBuffer(3);
buf.write(1); buf.write(2); buf.write(3);
buf.read() // => 1
buf.write(4);
buf.read() // => 2
```
hints: How does a circular buffer differ from a regular queue?
A circular buffer has a fixed capacity. Write appends, read removes from the front. Overwrite replaces the oldest when full.
Use an array with push and shift. For write, check capacity. For overwrite, shift first if at capacity, then push.

exercises.title: Crypto Square
exercises.description: Encode a message using the square code cipher.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `ciphertext(text)` that encodes a message:

1. Normalize: remove spaces/punctuation, lowercase
2. Arrange into a rectangle (r rows, c columns where c >= r, c - r <= 1, r*c >= length)
3. Read columns top-to-bottom, separated by spaces

```js
ciphertext("If man was meant to stay on the ground god would have given us roots")
// => "imtgdvs fearwer mayoogo anouuio ntnnlvt wttddes aede ss"
```
hints: How do you determine the dimensions of the rectangle for the square code?
Columns = ceil(sqrt(length)). Rows = ceil(length / columns). Pad with spaces if needed.
Normalize the text, compute rectangle dimensions, pad to fill, then read column by column.

exercises.title: Saddle Points
exercises.description: Find saddle points in a matrix (max in row, min in column).
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `saddlePoints(matrix)` that returns all saddle points.

A saddle point is an element that is >= all elements in its row and <= all elements in its column.

Return an array of `{row, column}` objects (1-indexed).

```js
saddlePoints([[9, 8, 7], [5, 3, 2], [6, 6, 7]])
// => [{row: 1, column: 3}]  (value 7 at row 1, col 3 -- but wait let me reconsider)
```
hints: What two conditions must be true for a saddle point?
A saddle point is the maximum in its row AND the minimum in its column.
For each element, check if it is >= all values in its row and <= all values in its column. Use every() for both checks.

exercises.title: Queen Attack
exercises.description: Determine if two queens on a chessboard can attack each other.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `QueenAttack` with:

- `constructor({ white, black })` - positions as [row, col] (0-7). Default white=[0,3], black=[7,3]
- `canAttack()` - returns true if queens can attack (same row, column, or diagonal)

Throw an error if positions are the same or out of bounds.

```js
const q = new QueenAttack({ white: [2, 2], black: [0, 4] });
q.canAttack() // => true (same diagonal)
```
hints: When can a queen attack another piece on the board?
Queens attack on the same row, same column, or same diagonal. Diagonals have equal absolute row and column differences.
Check: same row (wr === br), same column (wc === bc), or diagonal (|wr-br| === |wc-bc|).

exercises.title: Tournament
exercises.description: Parse tournament results and produce a formatted standings table.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `tournamentTally(input)` that takes match results and returns a formatted table.

Input format: one match per line as "Team1;Team2;result" where result is "win", "loss", or "draw" (from Team1 perspective).

Output: A header + rows sorted by points (desc), then name (asc). Columns: Team | MP | W | D | L | P

Win = 3pts, Draw = 1pt, Loss = 0pts.

```js
tournamentTally("A;B;win")
// => "Team                           | MP |  W |  D |  L |  P\nA                              |  1 |  1 |  0 |  0 |  3\nB                              |  1 |  0 |  0 |  1 |  0"
```
hints: How do you parse match results and aggregate team statistics?
Split input by newlines, parse each match, and maintain a stats object per team. Sort by points then name.
Track MP, W, D, L, P for each team. Format output with padEnd for team names and padStart for numbers.

exercises.title: State of Tic-Tac-Toe
exercises.description: Determine the state of a tic-tac-toe board: win, draw, or ongoing.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `gamestate(board)` that takes a 3x3 board (array of 3 strings like "X O", "OXX", etc.) and returns the game state.

Return:
- `"win"` if X or O has won
- `"draw"` if the board is full with no winner
- `"ongoing"` if the game is still in progress

Throw an error for invalid states (e.g., both players won, or wrong turn count).

```js
gamestate(["XXX", "OO.", "..."])  // => "win"
gamestate(["XOX", "XOX", "OXO"])  // => "draw"
gamestate(["X..", "...", "..."])  // => "ongoing"
```
hints: What are all the possible winning lines on a tic-tac-toe board?
Check 3 rows, 3 columns, and 2 diagonals. Also validate turn counts and reject impossible states.
Enumerate all 8 winning lines. Check if X or O wins. Validate that X count is equal to or one more than O count, and reject boards where play continued after a win.

exercises.title: Robot Simulator
exercises.description: Simulate a robot on a grid with position, direction, and instruction sequence.
exercises.instructions:
Write a class `Robot` with:

- `constructor()` - starts at (0,0) facing north
- `orient(direction)` - set direction: "north", "east", "south", "west"
- `turnRight()` / `turnLeft()` - rotate 90 degrees
- `advance()` - move one step in the current direction
- `at(x, y)` - set position
- `instructions(str)` - execute a string of L/R/A commands
- Properties: `bearing`, `coordinates`

```js
const r = new Robot();
r.at(0, 0); r.orient("north");
r.instructions("RAALAL");
r.coordinates // => [2, 1]
r.bearing     // => "west"
```
hints: How do you represent direction changes as rotations?
Store directions in order: north, east, south, west. Turning right adds 1 (mod 4), turning left adds 3 (mod 4).
For advance, change x or y based on current direction. For instructions, loop through each character and call the appropriate method.

exercises.title: Say (Number to Words)
exercises.description: Convert a number into its English word representation.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `say(number)` that converts a non-negative integer to English words.

Handle numbers from 0 to 999,999,999,999 (up to billions).

Throw an error for negative numbers or numbers >= 1 trillion.

```js
say(0)      // => "zero"
say(14)     // => "fourteen"
say(1002345) // => "one million two thousand three hundred forty-five"
```
hints: How do you break a large number into chunks of three digits?
Process the number in groups of 1000. Each group maps to ones/tens/hundreds words plus a scale (thousand, million, billion).
Use recursion or a helper to convert 0-999 to words. Process from right to left in groups of 3, prepending the scale word.

resources.label: MDN: Array.prototype.unshift()
resources.description: Add elements to the beginning of an array

exercises.title: Wordy
exercises.description: Parse and evaluate simple math word problems.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `answer(question)` that parses math questions in English.

Supported operations: plus, minus, multiplied by, divided by.

Operations are evaluated left-to-right (no precedence).

```js
answer("What is 5 plus 13?")            // => 18
answer("What is 7 minus 5 plus 1?")     // => 3
answer("What is 3 multiplied by 2?")    // => 6
```

Throw an error for unsupported operations or invalid format.
hints: How do you parse a sentence into numbers and operations?
Strip the question format, split into tokens, then process pairs of (operation, number) left-to-right.
Remove 'What is' and '?'. Split by whitespace. Read the first number, then loop: read an operator word, read the next number, apply.

exercises.title: Largest Series Product
exercises.description: Find the largest product of N consecutive digits in a number string.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `largestProduct(digits, span)` that finds the largest product of `span` consecutive digits.

Throw an error if span is negative, larger than the string length, or if the string contains non-digits.

```js
largestProduct("63915", 3) // => 135 (3*9*5 or 6*3*9=162... wait, 9*1*5=45, 6*3*9=162, 3*9*1=27, 9*1*5=45 => 162)
largestProduct("0000", 2)  // => 0
```
hints: How do you check every window of N consecutive digits?
Use a sliding window of the given span. For each window, compute the product of its digits.
Loop from index 0 to length - span. At each position, multiply the span digits together. Track the maximum product.

exercises.title: Forth Interpreter
exercises.description: Implement a basic Forth stack-based language interpreter.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `evaluate(instructions)` that implements a basic Forth interpreter.

Built-in operations:
- Numbers: push onto stack
- `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`: pop two, compute, push result (integer division)
- `DUP`: duplicate top of stack
- `DROP`: remove top of stack
- `SWAP`: swap top two elements
- `OVER`: copy second element to top
- `: word definition ;` - define a custom word

Return the stack as an array. Operations and definitions are case-insensitive.

```js
evaluate(["1 2 +"])        // => [3]
evaluate(["1 2 3", "DROP"]) // => [1, 2]
evaluate([": double 2 * ;", "5 double"]) // => [10]
```
hints: How does a stack-based language process tokens?
Process tokens left to right. Numbers go on the stack. Operators pop values, compute, and push results. Use a dictionary for custom definitions.

Maintain a stack array and a definitions object. For ':' definitions, capture the body tokens and expand any already-defined words. Execute tokens by checking if they are numbers, built-in ops, or custom words.

exercises.title: Remove From Array
exercises.description: Remove specified values from an array and return a new array without them.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `removeFromArray(arr, ...items)` that takes an array and one or more additional arguments, then returns a new array with all matching items removed.

```js
removeFromArray([1, 2, 3, 4], 3)       // => [1, 2, 4]
removeFromArray([1, 2, 3, 4], 3, 2)    // => [1, 4]
removeFromArray([1, 2, 3, 4], 7)       // => [1, 2, 3, 4]
removeFromArray(["a", "b", "c"], "b") // => ["a", "c"]
```
hints: How can you collect an unknown number of arguments after the first one?
Use rest parameters (...items) to gather extra arguments, then filter the array to exclude those items.
Use `arr.filter(el => !items.includes(el))` to return only elements not found in the items list.

resources.label: MDN: Rest parameters
resources.description: How rest parameters collect arguments into an array

resources.label: MDN: Array.prototype.filter()
resources.description: The filter method creates a new array with matching elements

exercises.title: Sum a Range
exercises.description: Sum all integers between two numbers, handling reversed arguments and invalid input.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `sumAll(range)` that takes a two-element array of numbers and returns the sum of all integers between them (inclusive). The arguments can be in any order. Return the string `"ERROR"` if either argument is negative or not a number.

```js
sumAll([1, 4])    // => 10 (1+2+3+4)
sumAll([4, 1])    // => 10 (works reversed)
sumAll([1, 1])    // => 1
sumAll([-1, 4])   // => "ERROR"
sumAll([1, "a"])  // => "ERROR"
```
hints: What should you check before starting the summation loop?
Validate inputs first (typeof check and negative check). Then find the lower and upper bounds with Math.min/Math.max and loop between them.
Destructure the array, return "ERROR" if either is not a number or is negative. Use a for loop from Math.min to Math.max, accumulating the sum.

resources.label: MDN: Math.min()
resources.description: Returns the smallest of the given numbers

resources.label: MDN: typeof
resources.description: The typeof operator returns a string indicating the type

exercises.title: Temperature Conversion
exercises.description: Convert temperatures between Fahrenheit and Celsius, rounded to one decimal place.
exercises.instructions:
Write two functions:

- `ftoc(f)` converts Fahrenheit to Celsius
- `ctof(c)` converts Celsius to Fahrenheit

Round results to 1 decimal place.

Formulas:
- C = (F - 32) * 5/9
- F = C * 9/5 + 32

```js
ftoc(32)   // => 0
ftoc(212)  // => 100
ftoc(-40)  // => -40
ctof(0)    // => 32
ctof(100)  // => 212
ctof(-40)  // => -40
```
hints: What are the formulas for converting between Fahrenheit and Celsius?
C = (F - 32) * 5/9 and F = C * 9/5 + 32. Use Math.round() with a multiplier to round to 1 decimal.
Compute the conversion, multiply by 10, round with Math.round(), then divide by 10 to get 1 decimal place.

resources.label: MDN: Math.round()
resources.description: Rounds a number to the nearest integer

resources.label: MDN: Arithmetic operators
resources.description: JavaScript arithmetic operators for math operations

exercises.title: Get the Titles
exercises.description: Extract an array of title strings from an array of book objects.
hints: What array method lets you transform each element into something else?
Array.map() creates a new array by applying a function to each element. You want to extract just the title property.
Use `books.map(book => book.title)` to pluck out the title from each book object.

resources.label: MDN: Array.prototype.map()
resources.description: Creates a new array by transforming each element

resources.label: MDN: Property accessors
resources.description: How to access object properties with dot or bracket notation

exercises.title: Find the Oldest
exercises.description: Find the person who has lived the longest from an array of people objects.
hints: How do you calculate someone's age if they might still be alive?
If yearOfDeath is missing, use the current year from new Date().getFullYear(). Then subtract yearOfBirth to get total years lived.
Use reduce to compare each person. For each, compute age = (yearOfDeath || currentYear) - yearOfBirth, and keep the one with the highest age.

resources.label: MDN: Array.prototype.reduce()
resources.description: Reduces an array to a single value by accumulating results

resources.label: MDN: Date.prototype.getFullYear()
resources.description: Returns the year of a Date object

exercises.title: Recursive Contains
exercises.description: Recursively search a nested array structure to find if it contains a given value.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `contains(arr, target)` that recursively searches through a nested array to determine if it contains the given target value. No loops allowed -- use only recursion.

The array can contain numbers, strings, or other arrays (nested arbitrarily deep).

```js
contains([1, [2, [3]]], 3)        // => true
contains([1, [2, [3]]], 4)        // => false
contains([], 1)                   // => false
contains([[[[5]]]], 5)            // => true
contains([1, "hello", [2]], "hello") // => true
```
hints: What are the base cases for a recursive search through a nested array?
Base cases: empty array returns false, matching element returns true. Recursive case: if the element is an array, recurse into it; otherwise check the rest.
Destructure [first, ...rest]. If first is an array, return contains(first, target) || contains(rest, target). If first === target, return true. Otherwise return contains(rest, target).

resources.label: MDN: Array.isArray()
resources.description: Determines whether a value is an array

resources.label: MDN: Destructuring assignment
resources.description: Unpack values from arrays into variables

exercises.title: Total Integers (Recursive)
exercises.description: Recursively count how many integers exist in a nested array structure.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `totalIntegers(arr)` that recursively counts how many integers appear in a nested array. Only count whole integers (not floats or other types). No loops allowed.

```js
totalIntegers([1, [2], 3])          // => 3
totalIntegers([[1, [2, 3]], [4]])    // => 4
totalIntegers([])                    // => 0
totalIntegers([1.5, "hello", 3])    // => 1 (only 3 is a whole integer)
totalIntegers([[[[7]]]])             // => 1
```
hints: How do you determine if a value is a whole integer versus a float or other type?
Use Number.isInteger() to check for whole integers. Recurse into sub-arrays and add up counts from each branch.
Destructure [first, ...rest]. If first is an array, return totalIntegers(first) + totalIntegers(rest). If Number.isInteger(first), add 1 + totalIntegers(rest). Otherwise 0 + totalIntegers(rest).

resources.label: MDN: Number.isInteger()
resources.description: Determines whether a value is an integer

resources.label: MDN: Array.isArray()
resources.description: Determines whether a value is an array

exercises.title: Permutations
exercises.description: Generate all permutations of a given string using recursion.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function `permutations(str)` that returns an array of all permutations of the given string. The order of permutations in the result does not matter.

```js
permutations("")     // => [""]
permutations("a")    // => ["a"]
permutations("ab")   // => ["ab", "ba"]
permutations("abc")  // => ["abc","acb","bac","bca","cab","cba"]
```

Hint: For each character in the string, fix it in the first position and recursively permute the remaining characters.
hints: What is the base case for generating permutations of a string?
For each character, remove it from the string and recursively find all permutations of the remaining characters. Prepend the removed character to each result.
Base case: strings of length 0 or 1 return [str]. Loop through each index i, take str[i] as the first char, recursively permute the rest, and prepend str[i] to each sub-permutation.

resources.label: MDN: String.prototype.slice()
