exercises.title: Define a Custom Property
exercises.description: Define a CSS custom property on :root and use it with var().
exercises.instructions:
CSS custom properties (also called CSS variables) let you store values and reuse them throughout your stylesheet.

1. On the `:root` selector, define a custom property `--primary-color` with the value `#3b82f6`
2. Set the `.box` element's `background-color` to use that custom property with `var(--primary-color)`
exercises.starterCode: /* Define your custom property on :root and use it */
hints: Custom properties always start with two dashes: --property-name
Define the property inside :root { --primary-color: #3b82f6; } then reference it with var(--primary-color)
The full solution: :root { --primary-color: #3b82f6; } .box { background-color: var(--primary-color); }

resources.label: MDN: Using CSS Custom Properties
resources.description: Complete guide to CSS custom properties (variables)

exercises.title: Theme with Custom Properties
exercises.description: Create a simple color theme using multiple custom properties.
exercises.instructions:
Build a basic theme system using custom properties.

1. On `:root`, define:
   - `--bg-color` as `#0f172a`
   - `--text-color` as `#e2e8f0`
   - `--accent-color` as `#f59e0b`
2. Apply `background-color: var(--bg-color)` to `.page`
3. Apply `color: var(--text-color)` to `.page`
4. Apply `color: var(--accent-color)` to `.highlight`
exercises.starterCode: /* Build your theme with custom properties */
hints: Define all three variables inside the :root selector
Each element uses var(--variable-name) to reference a custom property
:root { --bg-color: #0f172a; --text-color: #e2e8f0; --accent-color: #f59e0b; } then use var() on each

resources.label: MDN: var()
resources.description: The var() function for using custom properties

exercises.title: Fallback Values
exercises.description: Use var() with a fallback value for when a custom property is not defined.
exercises.instructions:
The `var()` function accepts a second argument as a fallback value.

1. Style `.card` with `background-color` using `var(--card-bg, #1e293b)` — the property `--card-bg` is NOT defined, so the fallback `#1e293b` should apply
2. Style `.card` with `color` using `var(--card-text, #f1f5f9)` — again using a fallback
3. Style `.card` with `padding` of `20px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use var() with fallback values */
hints: var() takes two arguments: var(--property, fallback-value)
When --card-bg is not defined anywhere, the fallback value is used automatically
.card { background-color: var(--card-bg, #1e293b); color: var(--card-text, #f1f5f9); padding: 20px; }

resources.label: MDN: var() — Fallback values
resources.description: How to provide fallback values in var()

exercises.title: calc() Basics
exercises.description: Use the calc() function to perform mathematical calculations in CSS.
exercises.instructions:
The `calc()` function lets you mix different units and do math in CSS values.

1. Set `.container` width to `calc(100% - 40px)` — full width minus some margin
2. Set `.container` padding to `20px`
3. Set `.container` height to `200px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use calc() for the width */
hints: calc() lets you combine different units: calc(100% - 40px)
Make sure there are spaces around the operator: calc(100% - 40px), not calc(100%-40px)
.container { width: calc(100% - 40px); padding: 20px; height: 200px; }

resources.label: MDN: calc()
resources.description: Perform calculations to determine CSS property values

exercises.title: calc() with Custom Properties
exercises.description: Combine calc() with CSS custom properties for dynamic calculations.
exercises.instructions:
Use `calc()` together with custom properties for flexible, reusable values.

1. On `:root`, define `--spacing` as `16px`
2. Set `.box` padding to `var(--spacing)` (16px)
3. Set `.box` margin to `calc(var(--spacing) * 2)` (32px)
4. Set `.box` width to `200px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Combine calc() with custom properties */
hints: Define --spacing on :root, then use var(--spacing) and calc(var(--spacing) * 2)
calc() can multiply a custom property: calc(var(--spacing) * 2) doubles the value
:root { --spacing: 16px; } .box { padding: var(--spacing); margin: calc(var(--spacing) * 2); width: 200px; }

resources.label: MDN: calc()
resources.description: Perform calculations with CSS custom properties

exercises.title: min() and max()
exercises.description: Use min() and max() for responsive sizing without media queries.
exercises.instructions:
The `min()` function picks the smallest value and `max()` picks the largest.

1. Set `.container` width to `min(100%, 600px)` — never wider than 600px
2. Set `.container` min-height to `max(200px, 50vh)` — at least 200px tall
3. Set `.container` padding to `16px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use min() and max() for responsive sizing */
hints: min() returns the smallest of its arguments: min(100%, 600px)
max() returns the largest: max(200px, 50vh) ensures a minimum size
.container { width: min(100%, 600px); min-height: max(200px, 50vh); padding: 16px; }

resources.label: MDN: min()
resources.description: Sets the smallest value from a list of comma-separated expressions

resources.label: MDN: max()
resources.description: Sets the largest value from a list of comma-separated expressions

exercises.title: clamp() for Fluid Typography
exercises.description: Use clamp() to create fluid typography that scales between breakpoints.
exercises.instructions:
The `clamp()` function takes three values: a minimum, a preferred, and a maximum.

1. Set `.heading` font-size to `clamp(1.5rem, 4vw, 3rem)` — fluid between 1.5rem and 3rem
2. Set `.body-text` font-size to `clamp(1rem, 2vw, 1.25rem)` — fluid between 1rem and 1.25rem
3. Set `.heading` line-height to `1.2`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use clamp() for fluid typography */
exercises.providedHtml:
Fluid Heading

This text scales smoothly between viewport sizes.
hints: clamp(minimum, preferred, maximum) — the browser picks the preferred value, clamped between min and max
For headings: clamp(1.5rem, 4vw, 3rem) means 'at least 1.5rem, ideally 4vw, at most 3rem'
.heading { font-size: clamp(1.5rem, 4vw, 3rem); line-height: 1.2; } .body-text { font-size: clamp(1rem, 2vw, 1.25rem); }

resources.label: MDN: clamp()
resources.description: Clamps a value between a minimum and maximum

exercises.title: clamp() for Layout Widths
exercises.description: Use clamp() to create a responsive container width.
exercises.instructions:
Use `clamp()` to make a container that is responsive without media queries.

1. Set `.wrapper` width to `clamp(320px, 80%, 960px)` — responsive between 320px and 960px
2. Set `.wrapper` margin to `0 auto` to center it
3. Set `.wrapper` padding to `24px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use clamp() for responsive layout width */
exercises.providedHtml: This container has a responsive width.
hints: clamp(min, preferred, max) for width: clamp(320px, 80%, 960px)
Center with margin: 0 auto — this works when the element has an explicit width
.wrapper { width: clamp(320px, 80%, 960px); margin: 0 auto; padding: 24px; }

resources.label: MDN: clamp()
resources.description: Clamp a value between a minimum and maximum

exercises.title: Combining CSS Functions
exercises.description: Combine multiple CSS math functions for advanced responsive calculations.
exercises.instructions:
CSS math functions can be nested inside each other for powerful calculations.

1. On `:root`, define `--sidebar-width` as `250px`
2. Set `.main-content` width to `calc(100% - var(--sidebar-width))` — remaining space after sidebar
3. Set `.main-content` padding to `clamp(16px, 3vw, 48px)` — fluid padding
4. Set `.main-content` min-height to `200px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Combine CSS functions for advanced layouts */

testCases.description: CSS uses var() for custom properties

hints: calc() can reference custom properties: calc(100% - var(--sidebar-width))
clamp() works independently from calc() — use it on padding for fluid spacing
:root { --sidebar-width: 250px; } .main-content { width: calc(100% - var(--sidebar-width)); padding: clamp(16px, 3vw, 48px); min-height: 200px; }

resources.label: MDN: CSS Value Functions
resources.description: Overview of all CSS value functions

exercises.title: Spacing Scale with Custom Properties
exercises.description: Create a consistent spacing scale using CSS custom properties.
exercises.instructions:
Design systems use spacing scales for consistency. Build one with custom properties.

1. On `:root`, define:
   - `--space-xs` as `4px`
   - `--space-sm` as `8px`
   - `--space-md` as `16px`
   - `--space-lg` as `32px`
2. Set `.card` padding to `var(--space-md)` (16px)
3. Set `.card` margin-bottom to `var(--space-lg)` (32px)
4. Set `.card-title` margin-bottom to `var(--space-sm)` (8px)
exercises.starterCode: /* Create a spacing scale with custom properties */
hints: Define all spacing values on :root: --space-xs: 4px; --space-sm: 8px; etc.
Use var(--space-md) for padding, var(--space-lg) for margin-bottom on .card
The spacing scale: xs=4px, sm=8px, md=16px, lg=32px. Apply using var() on each element.

resources.label: MDN: Using CSS Custom Properties
resources.description: Guide to creating design token systems with custom properties

exercises.title: :is() Selector
exercises.description: Use the :is() pseudo-class to simplify grouped selectors.
exercises.instructions:
The `:is()` pseudo-class reduces repetition when targeting multiple selectors.

1. Use `:is(h1, h2, h3)` to set `color` to `#3b82f6` on all three heading levels at once
2. Use `:is(h1, h2, h3)` to set `margin-bottom` to `12px` on all three
exercises.starterCode: /* Use :is() to group selectors */
hints: :is() takes a list of selectors: :is(h1, h2, h3) { ... }
This is equivalent to writing h1, h2, h3 { ... } but is more composable in complex selectors
:is(h1, h2, h3) { color: #3b82f6; margin-bottom: 12px; }

resources.label: MDN: :is()
resources.description: Matches any element that matches any of the selectors in its list

exercises.title: :where() Selector
exercises.description: Use :where() for zero-specificity selector grouping.
exercises.instructions:
`:where()` works like `:is()` but has zero specificity — making it easy to override.

1. Use `:where(h1, h2, h3)` to set `font-weight` to `600`
2. Use `:where(h1, h2, h3)` to set `line-height` to `1.3`
3. Set `h1` color to `#ef4444` — this easily overrides `:where()` because :where has zero specificity
exercises.starterCode: /* Use :where() for low-specificity defaults */
hints: :where() syntax is identical to :is() — :where(h1, h2, h3) { ... }
The difference: :where() has zero specificity, so any direct selector can override it
:where(h1, h2, h3) { font-weight: 600; line-height: 1.3; } h1 { color: #ef4444; }

exercises.title: :not() Advanced
exercises.description: Use :not() to exclude specific elements from a style rule.
exercises.instructions:
The `:not()` pseudo-class excludes elements that match the given selector.

1. Select `.item:not(:last-child)` and set `margin-bottom` to `12px` — adds spacing between items but not after the last one
2. Select `.item:not(.disabled)` and set `color` to `#e2e8f0`
3. Select `.item.disabled` and set `opacity` to `0.4`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use :not() to exclude elements */
exercises.providedHtml:
Active Item 1
Disabled Item
Active Item 2
hints: :not(:last-child) targets every element except the last one
You can also exclude by class: .item:not(.disabled) targets items without the .disabled class
.item:not(:last-child) { margin-bottom: 12px; } .item:not(.disabled) { color: #e2e8f0; } .item.disabled { opacity: 0.4; }

resources.label: MDN: :not()
resources.description: Matches elements that do not match the given selector

exercises.title: :has() Parent Selector
exercises.description: Use :has() to style a parent element based on its children.
exercises.instructions:
The `:has()` pseudo-class is often called the "parent selector" — it styles an element based on what it contains.

1. Style `.card:has(img)` with `padding` of `0` — cards with images have no padding
2. Style `.card:not(:has(img))` with `padding` of `24px` — cards without images keep padding
3. Set all `.card` elements to have `border-radius` of `8px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use :has() to style parents based on children */
exercises.providedHtml:
Card with image

Card without image
hints: :has() checks if an element contains something: .card:has(img) targets cards that contain an img
Combine :not() with :has() to target the opposite: .card:not(:has(img))
.card { border-radius: 8px; } .card:has(img) { padding: 0; } .card:not(:has(img)) { padding: 24px; }

resources.label: MDN: :has()
resources.description: Style a parent based on its children — the 'parent selector'

exercises.title: :has() Form Validation Styling
exercises.description: Use :has() with sibling selectors to style form fields based on validation state.
exercises.instructions:
Use `:has()` to style form groups based on adjacent error messages.

1. Style `.form-group:has(.error)` with a left `border-left` of `3px solid #ef4444` (red border when error is present)
2. Style `.form-group:not(:has(.error))` with a left `border-left` of `3px solid #22c55e` (green border when no error)
3. Set `.form-group` padding-left to `12px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use :has() for form validation styling */
exercises.providedHtml: Invalid email

testCases.description: Form group with .error has red border
Form group without .error has green border

hints: .form-group:has(.error) targets form groups that contain an element with class .error
Combine :not(:has(.error)) for the opposite — groups without errors
.form-group { padding-left: 12px; } .form-group:has(.error) { border-left: 3px solid #ef4444; } .form-group:not(:has(.error)) { border-left: 3px solid #22c55e; }

resources.label: MDN: :has()
resources.description: Style parents based on child state

exercises.title: Attribute Selectors
exercises.description: Use attribute selectors to style elements based on data attributes.
exercises.instructions:
Attribute selectors target elements by their attributes.

1. Style `[data-status="active"]` with `color` of `#22c55e` (green)
2. Style `[data-status="inactive"]` with `color` of `#94a3b8` (gray)
3. Style `[data-status="error"]` with `color` of `#ef4444` (red)
exercises.starterCode: /* Use attribute selectors */
hints: Attribute selectors use square brackets: [attribute="value"]
data-* attributes are custom HTML attributes you can target with CSS
[data-status="active"] { color: #22c55e; } [data-status="inactive"] { color: #94a3b8; } [data-status="error"] { color: #ef4444; }

resources.label: MDN: Attribute Selectors
resources.description: Select elements based on their attributes

exercises.title: Combining Modern Selectors
exercises.description: Combine :is(), :not(), and :has() in a single stylesheet.
exercises.instructions:
Combine modern selectors for powerful, concise CSS.

1. Use `:is(h1, h2)` to set `font-family` to `Georgia, serif`
2. Style `.list-item:not(:last-child)` with `border-bottom` of `1px solid #334155`
3. Style `.section:has(.highlight)` with `background-color` of `rgba(59, 130, 246, 0.1)`
4. Style `.section:not(:has(.highlight))` with `background-color` of `transparent`
exercises.starterCode: /* Combine :is(), :not(), and :has() */
exercises.providedHtml:
Title

Highlighted

Subtitle

Normal

Item 1
Item 2
Item 3
hints: :is(h1, h2) groups selectors, :not(:last-child) excludes the last element
:has(.highlight) targets elements containing a .highlight child
Combine all three: :is() for grouping headings, :not() for list spacing, :has() for conditional backgrounds

exercises.title: aspect-ratio
exercises.description: Use the aspect-ratio property to maintain proportional dimensions.
exercises.instructions:
The `aspect-ratio` property sets a preferred aspect ratio for an element.

1. Set `.video-container` to `aspect-ratio: 16 / 9`
2. Set `.video-container` width to `100%`
3. Set `.video-container` max-width to `640px`
4. Set `.video-container` background-color to `#1e293b`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use aspect-ratio for proportional sizing */
hints: aspect-ratio takes a ratio: aspect-ratio: 16 / 9
Combine with width: 100% and max-width for responsive sizing
.video-container { aspect-ratio: 16 / 9; width: 100%; max-width: 640px; background-color: #1e293b; }

resources.label: MDN: aspect-ratio
resources.description: Sets a preferred aspect ratio for the box

exercises.title: object-fit
exercises.description: Use object-fit to control how images fill their container.
exercises.instructions:
The `object-fit` property controls how replaced elements (like images) fill their box.

1. Set `.thumbnail` to `object-fit: cover` — the image fills the box, cropping if needed
2. Set `.thumbnail` width to `200px`
3. Set `.thumbnail` height to `200px`
4. Set `.thumbnail` border-radius to `8px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use object-fit to control image display */
hints: object-fit: cover fills the entire area, cropping if the aspect ratio doesn't match
Other values include: contain, fill, none, scale-down
.thumbnail { object-fit: cover; width: 200px; height: 200px; border-radius: 8px; }

resources.label: MDN: object-fit
resources.description: How replaced elements should be resized to fit their container

exercises.title: Logical Properties
exercises.description: Use CSS logical properties for direction-agnostic layouts.
exercises.instructions:
Logical properties use `inline` (horizontal) and `block` (vertical) instead of left/right/top/bottom, making layouts work in any writing direction.

1. Set `.card` `padding-inline` to `24px` (horizontal padding)
2. Set `.card` `padding-block` to `16px` (vertical padding)
3. Set `.card` `margin-block-end` to `20px` (bottom margin in LTR)
4. Set `.card` `border-inline-start` to `4px solid #3b82f6` (left border in LTR)
exercises.starterCode: /* Use logical properties instead of physical ones */
exercises.providedHtml: Logical properties adapt to any writing direction.
hints: inline = horizontal direction (left/right in LTR). block = vertical direction (top/bottom)
padding-inline sets both left and right padding; padding-block sets both top and bottom
.card { padding-inline: 24px; padding-block: 16px; margin-block-end: 20px; border-inline-start: 4px solid #3b82f6; }

exercises.title: gap in Flexbox
exercises.description: Use the gap property with flexbox for clean spacing between items.
exercises.instructions:
The `gap` property works in flexbox to add space between items (but not around the edges).

1. Set `.toolbar` to `display: flex`
2. Set `.toolbar` `align-items` to `center`
3. Set `.toolbar` `gap` to `12px`
4. Set `.toolbar` `padding` to `16px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use gap with flexbox */
hints: gap works in both flexbox and grid — it adds space between children
Unlike margin, gap only adds space between items, not around the outside
.toolbar { display: flex; align-items: center; gap: 12px; padding: 16px; }

exercises.title: Subgrid
exercises.description: Use subgrid to align nested grid items with the parent grid.
exercises.instructions:
Subgrid lets a nested grid item inherit its parent's grid tracks.

1. Set `.grid-parent` to `display: grid` with `grid-template-columns: 1fr 2fr 1fr` and `gap` of `16px`
2. Set `.grid-child` to `display: grid` and `grid-template-columns: subgrid`
3. Set `.grid-child` to span all 3 columns with `grid-column: 1 / -1`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use subgrid to align nested content */
hints: A subgrid child uses its parent's column/row tracks instead of defining its own
The child must span multiple tracks: grid-column: 1 / -1 spans all columns
.grid-parent { display: grid; grid-template-columns: 1fr 2fr 1fr; gap: 16px; } .grid-child { display: grid; grid-template-columns: subgrid; grid-column: 1 / -1; }

resources.label: MDN: Subgrid
resources.description: Inherit parent grid tracks in nested grids

exercises.title: Auto-fill vs Auto-fit
exercises.description: Use repeat() with auto-fill or auto-fit for responsive grid layouts.
exercises.instructions:
Create a responsive grid that automatically adjusts the number of columns.

1. Set `.grid` to `display: grid`
2. Set `.grid` `grid-template-columns` to `repeat(auto-fill, minmax(200px, 1fr))` — fills available space with columns at least 200px wide
3. Set `.grid` `gap` to `16px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Create a responsive auto-fill grid */
hints: repeat(auto-fill, minmax(200px, 1fr)) creates as many 200px+ columns as fit
auto-fill creates empty tracks when there's extra space; auto-fit collapses them
.grid { display: grid; grid-template-columns: repeat(auto-fill, minmax(200px, 1fr)); gap: 16px; }

resources.label: MDN: repeat()
resources.description: Repeat track listing with auto-fill or auto-fit

exercises.title: Content-Based Sizing
exercises.description: Use intrinsic sizing keywords for content-aware layouts.
exercises.instructions:
CSS offers intrinsic sizing keywords that size elements based on their content.

1. Set `.min-box` width to `min-content` — as narrow as the longest word
2. Set `.max-box` width to `max-content` — as wide as the content without wrapping
3. Set `.fit-box` width to `fit-content(300px)` — content width up to 300px max
4. Set all three to have `padding` of `12px` and `margin-bottom` of `8px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use intrinsic sizing keywords */
exercises.providedHtml:
Some longer text content here
Some longer text content here
Some longer text content here
hints: min-content: width of the longest word. max-content: width of content without wrapping.
fit-content(300px) is like min(max-content, max(min-content, 300px))
.min-box { width: min-content; } .max-box { width: max-content; } .fit-box { width: fit-content(300px); }

resources.label: MDN: min-content
resources.description: Intrinsic minimum width of the content

exercises.title: backdrop-filter
exercises.description: Use backdrop-filter to create a frosted glass effect.
exercises.instructions:
The `backdrop-filter` property applies effects to the area behind an element.

1. Set `.glass-panel` `backdrop-filter` to `blur(10px)`
2. Set `.glass-panel` `background-color` to `rgba(15, 23, 42, 0.6)` (semi-transparent)
3. Set `.glass-panel` `padding` to `24px`
4. Set `.glass-panel` `border-radius` to `12px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Create a frosted glass effect */
hints: backdrop-filter: blur(10px) blurs everything behind the element
Combine with a semi-transparent background for the glass effect
.glass-panel { backdrop-filter: blur(10px); background-color: rgba(15, 23, 42, 0.6); padding: 24px; border-radius: 12px; }

resources.label: MDN: backdrop-filter
resources.description: Apply graphical effects to the area behind an element

exercises.title: color-mix()
exercises.description: Use color-mix() to blend two colors together in CSS.
exercises.instructions:
The `color-mix()` function blends two colors in a specified color space.

1. Set `.mixed-bg` background-color to `color-mix(in srgb, #3b82f6 50%, #ef4444 50%)` — a 50/50 mix of blue and red
2. Set `.mixed-bg` padding to `24px`
3. Set `.mixed-bg` color to `white`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use color-mix() to blend colors */
hints: color-mix(in srgb, color1 percentage, color2 percentage) blends two colors
The 'in srgb' part specifies the color space for mixing
.mixed-bg { background-color: color-mix(in srgb, #3b82f6 50%, #ef4444 50%); padding: 24px; color: white; }

resources.label: MDN: color-mix()
resources.description: Mix two colors together in a given color space

exercises.title: accent-color
exercises.description: Use accent-color to theme native form controls.
exercises.instructions:
The `accent-color` property changes the accent color of form controls like checkboxes and radio buttons.

1. Set `.form-controls` `accent-color` to `#8b5cf6` (purple)
2. Set `.form-controls` `font-size` to `16px`
3. Set `.form-controls input` `margin-right` to `8px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use accent-color to theme form controls */
hints: accent-color changes the color of checkboxes, radio buttons, range inputs, and progress bars
It inherits, so set it on a parent to affect all child form controls
.form-controls { accent-color: #8b5cf6; font-size: 16px; } .form-controls input { margin-right: 8px; }

resources.label: MDN: accent-color
resources.description: Set the accent color for user-interface controls

exercises.title: Scroll Snap
exercises.description: Use CSS scroll snap for smooth, snapping scroll behavior.
exercises.instructions:
CSS Scroll Snap creates smooth snapping points while scrolling.

1. Set `.carousel` `scroll-snap-type` to `x mandatory` (horizontal snapping)
2. Set `.carousel` to `display: flex` and `overflow-x: auto`
3. Set `.carousel` `gap` to `16px`
4. Set `.slide` `scroll-snap-align` to `start`
5. Set `.slide` `min-width` to `300px` and `flex-shrink` to `0`
exercises.starterCode: /* Create a scroll-snapping carousel */
hints: The container needs scroll-snap-type and the children need scroll-snap-align
x mandatory = horizontal snapping, always snaps to a point after scrolling
.carousel { scroll-snap-type: x mandatory; display: flex; overflow-x: auto; } .slide { scroll-snap-align: start; min-width: 300px; }

exercises.title: Smooth Scrolling
exercises.description: Enable smooth scrolling with a single CSS property.
exercises.instructions:
The `scroll-behavior` property enables smooth scrolling for anchor links.

1. Set `html` `scroll-behavior` to `smooth`
2. Set `.section` `min-height` to `200px`
3. Set `.section` `padding` to `20px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Enable smooth scrolling */
exercises.providedHtml:
Section 1 Section 2
Section 1
Section 2
hints: Set scroll-behavior: smooth on the html element to enable smooth anchor scrolling
This affects all scrolling triggered by anchor links (#id) on the page
html { scroll-behavior: smooth; } .section { min-height: 200px; padding: 20px; }

resources.label: MDN: scroll-behavior
resources.description: Control the scrolling behavior for anchor navigation

exercises.title: outline-offset for Focus Styles
exercises.description: Use outline-offset to create visible, accessible focus indicators.
exercises.instructions:
The `outline-offset` property spaces the outline away from the element border.

1. Set `.btn:focus-visible` `outline` to `2px solid #3b82f6`
2. Set `.btn:focus-visible` `outline-offset` to `3px` — creates a visible gap between button and outline
3. Set `.btn` `padding` to `12px 24px`
4. Set `.btn` `border-radius` to `6px`
5. Set `.btn` `border` to `1px solid #475569`
exercises.starterCode: /* Style focus outlines with offset */
hints: outline-offset pushes the outline away from the element's edge
:focus-visible only shows the outline for keyboard focus, not mouse clicks
.btn { padding: 12px 24px; border-radius: 6px; border: 1px solid #475569; } .btn:focus-visible { outline: 2px solid #3b82f6; outline-offset: 3px; }

resources.label: MDN: outline-offset
resources.description: Set the space between an outline and the edge of an element

exercises.title: Container Queries Basics
exercises.description: Use container queries to style elements based on their container's size.
exercises.instructions:
Container queries let you style elements based on the size of their parent container, not the viewport.

1. Set `.card-wrapper` `container-type` to `inline-size` — this marks it as a query container
2. Set `.card` `padding` to `16px`
3. Write a `@container` rule: when the container is at least `400px` wide, set `.card` padding to `32px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use container queries */
hints: First, mark the parent as a container with container-type: inline-size
Then use @container (min-width: 400px) { ... } to apply conditional styles
.card-wrapper { container-type: inline-size; } .card { padding: 16px; } @container (min-width: 400px) { .card { padding: 32px; } }

resources.label: MDN: CSS Container Queries
resources.description: Style elements based on their container's size

exercises.title: Container Query Sizing
exercises.description: Use container query units and multiple breakpoints.
exercises.instructions:
Container queries support multiple breakpoints and container query units like `cqw`.

1. Set `.widget-container` `container-type` to `inline-size`
2. Set `.widget` `font-size` to `14px` and `display` to `block` (default)
3. At `@container (min-width: 300px)`, set `.widget` `font-size` to `16px`
4. At `@container (min-width: 500px)`, set `.widget` `font-size` to `18px` and `display` to `flex` with `gap` of `16px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use multiple container query breakpoints */
hints: You can have multiple @container rules at different sizes, like media query breakpoints
Container query units: 1cqw = 1% of container width, 1cqh = 1% of container height
Define multiple @container (min-width: ...) blocks that progressively enhance the layout

resources.label: MDN: Container Query Length Units
resources.description: Use cqw, cqh, and other container-relative units

exercises.title: Named Containers
exercises.description: Use named containers to target specific query containers.
exercises.instructions:
Named containers let you target a specific ancestor container in your queries.

1. Set `.sidebar` `container-type` to `inline-size` and `container-name` to `sidebar`
2. Set `.main` `container-type` to `inline-size` and `container-name` to `main`
3. Write `@container sidebar (min-width: 200px)` to set `.nav-item` `font-size` to `14px`
4. Write `@container main (min-width: 400px)` to set `.content` `font-size` to `18px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use named containers for targeted queries */
exercises.providedHtml:
Nav
Content
hints: container-name gives your container an identifier: container-name: sidebar
Then query it specifically: @container sidebar (min-width: 200px) { ... }
This prevents children from accidentally matching an outer container

exercises.title: CSS Nesting Basics
exercises.description: Use native CSS nesting to write cleaner, more organized stylesheets.
exercises.instructions:
Native CSS nesting lets you nest selectors inside parent rules using `&`.

1. Style `.card` with `padding` of `20px` and `border-radius` of `8px`
2. Inside `.card`, nest `.card-title` (using `& .card-title` or `.card-title` with nesting) with `font-size` of `20px` and `margin-bottom` of `8px`
3. Inside `.card`, nest `.card-body` with `font-size` of `14px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use CSS nesting */
hints: Native CSS nesting: put child selectors inside the parent rule block
You can use & to explicitly reference the parent: & .card-title { ... }
.card { padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px; .card-title { font-size: 20px; margin-bottom: 8px; } .card-body { font-size: 14px; } }

exercises.title: Nesting with Media Queries
exercises.description: Nest @media queries inside selectors for co-located responsive styles.
exercises.instructions:
With CSS nesting, you can place `@media` rules inside selectors — keeping responsive styles next to the properties they modify.

1. Style `.hero` with `padding` of `20px` and `font-size` of `16px`
2. Inside `.hero`, nest a `@media (min-width: 768px)` rule that changes `padding` to `40px` and `font-size` to `24px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Nest media queries inside selectors */
hints: With nesting, @media goes inside the selector: .hero { @media (...) { ... } }
The nested @media implicitly applies to .hero — you don't repeat the selector
.hero { padding: 20px; font-size: 16px; @media (min-width: 768px) { padding: 40px; font-size: 24px; } }

resources.label: MDN: CSS Nesting At-rules
resources.description: Nesting @media and other at-rules inside selectors

exercises.title: Nesting with Pseudo-classes
exercises.description: Use the & nesting selector with pseudo-classes for interactive styles.
exercises.instructions:
The `&` nesting selector is required when nesting pseudo-classes.

1. Style `.btn` with `padding` of `12px 24px`, `background-color` of `#3b82f6`, `color` of `white`, and `border-radius` of `6px`
2. Nest `&:hover` inside `.btn` with `background-color` of `#2563eb`
3. Nest `&:active` inside `.btn` with `background-color` of `#1d4ed8`
4. Set `.btn` `border` to `none`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use & for nesting pseudo-classes */
hints: & references the parent selector: &:hover means .btn:hover when nested inside .btn
Pseudo-classes always need & when nesting: &:hover, &:focus, &:active
.btn { padding: 12px 24px; background-color: #3b82f6; &:hover { background-color: #2563eb; } &:active { background-color: #1d4ed8; } }

resources.label: MDN: Nesting Selector (&)
resources.description: The & nesting selector for pseudo-classes and compound selectors

exercises.title: Design Token System
exercises.description: Build a complete design token system with custom properties.
exercises.instructions:
Create a comprehensive design token system on `:root` and apply it.

1. On `:root`, define:
   - `--color-primary` as `#3b82f6`
   - `--color-surface` as `#1e293b`
   - `--color-text` as `#e2e8f0`
   - `--font-body` as `'Inter', sans-serif`
   - `--radius-md` as `8px`
   - `--shadow-md` as `0 4px 12px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3)`
2. Apply to `.card`: background-color from `--color-surface`, color from `--color-text`, font-family from `--font-body`, border-radius from `--radius-md`, box-shadow from `--shadow-md`, and padding of `24px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Build a design token system */
exercises.providedHtml:
Token-Driven Card

Styled entirely with design tokens.
hints: Design tokens are a naming convention for custom properties that group values by purpose
Common categories: --color-*, --font-*, --radius-*, --shadow-*, --space-*
Define all tokens on :root, then reference them with var(--token-name) throughout your CSS

resources.label: MDN: Using CSS Custom Properties
resources.description: Building design systems with CSS custom properties

exercises.title: Responsive Card Without Media Queries
exercises.description: Build a fully responsive card using only modern CSS functions — no media queries.
exercises.instructions:
Create a responsive card using `clamp()`, `min()`, and modern layout features.

1. Set `.card-container` `container-type` to `inline-size`
2. Set `.card` padding to `clamp(16px, 4cqw, 32px)` — fluid based on container
3. Set `.card` width to `min(100%, 500px)` — never wider than 500px
4. Set `.card` `font-size` to `clamp(14px, 2cqw, 18px)` — fluid font
5. Set `.card` `border-radius` to `8px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Build a responsive card without @media */
exercises.providedHtml:
Responsive Card

This card adapts using only CSS functions.

testCases.description: width is constrained to 500px max via min()

hints: clamp(min, preferred, max) with cqw units: fluid sizing based on container width
min(100%, 500px) acts as a max-width without needing the max-width property
container-type: inline-size on the parent enables cqw units in the children

resources.label: MDN: CSS Container Queries
resources.description: Container queries and container query units

exercises.title: Dark Mode with Custom Properties
exercises.description: Implement dark/light mode switching using custom properties and data attributes.
exercises.instructions:
Build a dark/light mode system using custom properties and `[data-theme]` attribute selectors.

1. On `[data-theme="dark"]`, define:
   - `--bg` as `#0f172a`
   - `--text` as `#e2e8f0`
   - `--surface` as `#1e293b`
2. On `[data-theme="light"]`, define:
   - `--bg` as `#ffffff`
   - `--text` as `#1e293b`
   - `--surface` as `#f1f5f9`
3. Set `.page` background-color to `var(--bg)` and color to `var(--text)`
4. Set `.card` background-color to `var(--surface)` and padding to `20px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Implement dark/light mode with custom properties */
exercises.providedHtml:
Theme Card

This adapts to the theme.
hints: Define different variable values under different [data-theme] selectors
Components use var(--bg) etc. — they don't know which theme is active
[data-theme='dark'] { --bg: #0f172a; } [data-theme='light'] { --bg: #fff; } Then .page { background-color: var(--bg); }

exercises.title: Modern Layout Composition
exercises.description: Compose a complete layout using grid, custom properties, container queries, clamp(), and nesting.
exercises.instructions:
Build a dashboard layout combining multiple modern CSS features.

1. On `:root`, define `--gap` as `16px` and `--radius` as `8px`
2. Set `.dashboard` to `display: grid` with `grid-template-columns: 250px 1fr` and `gap: var(--gap)`
3. Set `.dashboard` `container-type` to `inline-size`
4. Set `.panel` with `background-color` `#1e293b`, `border-radius` `var(--radius)`, and `padding` `clamp(12px, 2cqw, 24px)` (use nesting for organization)
5. Inside `.panel`, nest `.panel-title` with `font-size` of `18px` and `margin-bottom` of `var(--gap)`
6. At `@container (max-width: 600px)`, change `.dashboard` to `grid-template-columns: 1fr` (single column)
exercises.starterCode: /* Build a modern dashboard layout */
exercises.providedHtml:
Sidebar

Navigation

Main Content

Dashboard widgets go here.

testCases.description: CSS uses clamp() for fluid sizing

hints: This exercise combines everything: custom properties for tokens, grid for layout, clamp() for fluid sizing, container queries for responsiveness, and nesting for organization
Start with :root tokens, then the grid layout, then style individual panels with nesting
The @container query goes outside the nesting — it changes the grid at narrow widths

exercises.title: CSS Methods
exercises.description: Practice applying CSS styles using class selectors. Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
Style three elements to practice basic CSS properties.

1. Style `.external` with:
   - `background-color: red`
   - `color: white`
   - `font-size: 32px`
   - `text-align: center`
   - `font-weight: bold`
2. Style `.internal` with:
   - `background-color: green`
   - `color: white`
   - `font-size: 18px`
3. Style `.inline-style` with:
   - `background-color: orange`
   - `font-size: 18px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Style the three elements */
exercises.providedHtml:
External Style

Internal Style
hints: Each selector targets a class: .external { ... }
CSS color keywords like red, white, green, orange are valid values
font-weight: bold is equivalent to font-weight: 700

exercises.title: Class & ID Selectors
exercises.description: Practice using class and ID selectors to style elements. Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
Use class and ID selectors to apply styles.

1. Style `.odd` with `background-color: rgba(255, 167, 167, 0.5)` (light red/pink)
2. Style `#second` with `color: blue` and `font-size: 36px`
3. Style `#fourth` with `background-color: rgba(144, 238, 144, 0.5)` (light green) and `font-size: 24px`
4. Style `.bold-text` with `font-weight: bold`
exercises.starterCode: /* Use class and ID selectors */
exercises.providedHtml:
Item 1

Item 2

Item 3

Item 4

Item 5
hints: Classes use a dot: .odd { ... }. IDs use a hash: #second { ... }
An element can have multiple classes: class='odd bold-text'
Use rgba() for semi-transparent colors

exercises.title: Grouping Selectors
exercises.description: Use grouping selectors to share styles between elements. Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
Two elements share some styles but differ in others. Use a grouping selector for shared styles.

1. Use a grouped selector `.heading, .subheading` to set:
   - `font-family: Helvetica, 'Times New Roman', sans-serif`
   - `font-size: 28px`
2. Style `.heading` individually with `background-color: black` and `color: white`
3. Style `.subheading` individually with `background-color: yellow`
exercises.starterCode: /* Group shared styles, then add unique styles */
hints: Group selectors with a comma: .heading, .subheading { shared styles }
Then write separate rules for unique styles per element
Grouping reduces code duplication

exercises.title: Chaining Selectors
exercises.description: Chain CSS class selectors to target elements with multiple classes. Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
Two images share the `.avatar` class but have different second classes. Use chaining to style each differently.

1. Style `.avatar` (shared) with `border-radius: 50%`
2. Style `.avatar.proportioned` (chained) with `width: 300px` and `height: 300px`
3. Style `.avatar.distorted` (chained) with `width: 200px` and `height: 400px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Chain selectors to target specific elements */
hints: Chaining means no space between selectors: .avatar.proportioned targets elements with BOTH classes
This is different from .avatar .proportioned (descendant) — chaining has no space
.avatar { shared } .avatar.proportioned { unique } .avatar.distorted { unique }

resources.label: MDN: Class Selectors
resources.description: Chaining class selectors for higher specificity

` elements that are inside a `

`, leaving other paragraphs unstyled. 1. Use the descendant combinator `div p` to set: - `background-color: yellow` - `color: red` - `font-size: 20px` - `text-align: center`

Inside a div

Outside any div

p inside div has red text

exercises.title: Margin & Padding 1

exercises.title: Cascade Fix
exercises.description: Fix CSS cascade specificity issues so styles apply correctly. Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
The CSS below has cascade/specificity issues. Fix the selectors so the correct styles win.

1. Style `.alert` with `color: #94a3b8` (gray default text)
2. Style `.alert.success` with `color: #22c55e` (green) — must override .alert
3. Style `.alert.error` with `color: #ef4444` (red) — must override .alert
4. Style `.title` with `font-size: 18px`
5. Style `h1.title` with `font-size: 28px` — must override .title via higher specificity
exercises.starterCode: /* Fix the cascade so each style applies correctly */
exercises.providedHtml:
Default alert

Success alert

Error alert

Regular title

Main title
hints: Higher specificity wins: .alert.success (2 classes) beats .alert (1 class)
h1.title (element + class) has higher specificity than .title (class only)
Chained selectors increase specificity: .alert.success > .alert

Header
Sidebar
Content

exercises.title: Responsive Grid Layout

exercises.instructions:
Make the Holy Grail layout responsive by using `fr` units instead of fixed pixels.

3. Set `grid-template-rows` to `1fr 5fr 1fr` (middle row is 5× taller)

exercises.starterCode: /* Make the grid responsive with fr units */
exercises.providedHtml:
Header
Sidebar
Content
Footer
hints: fr units are fractional — 1fr 3fr means the second column is 3x wider than the first
1fr 5fr 1fr for rows makes the middle row 5x taller than header and footer
fr units make the layout flexible and responsive without media queries

exercises.title: Grid with Auto-fit Cards
exercises.description: Create a responsive card grid using auto-fit and minmax(). Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
Build a grid layout with an auto-adjusting card section.

1. Set `.card-grid` to `display: grid`
2. Set `grid-template-columns` to `repeat(auto-fit, minmax(250px, 1fr))` — cards auto-adjust
3. Set `gap` to `16px`
4. Set `.grid-card` `height` to `200px`, `padding` to `16px`, and `border-radius` to `8px`

hints: repeat(auto-fit, minmax(250px, 1fr)) creates as many columns as fit, each at least 250px
auto-fit collapses empty tracks, so cards stretch to fill available space
This creates a fully responsive grid without any media queries

exercises.title: Button Hover Transition
exercises.description: Create a smooth button hover animation using transitions. Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
Make a button that smoothly enlarges when hovered.

1. Set `.hover-btn` to `padding: 12px 24px`, `border: none`, `border-radius: 6px`, `background-color: #3b82f6`, `color: white`, `font-size: 16px`
2. Add `transition: transform 0.3s ease` for smooth animation
3. On `.hover-btn:hover`, set `transform: scale(1.1)` to enlarge by 10%
exercises.starterCode: /* Create a hover transition */
hints: transition goes on the base state (not :hover) so it animates both in and out
transform: scale(1.1) enlarges the element by 10%
transition: transform 0.3s ease makes the scale change smooth

exercises.title: Pop-up Animation
exercises.description: Animate a pop-up dialog with slide and fade transitions. Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
Create a pop-up that slides down and fades in.

1. Set `.popup` base state: `opacity: 0`, `transform: translateY(-30px)`, and `transition: opacity 0.3s ease, transform 0.3s ease`
2. Set `.popup.visible`: `opacity: 1` and `transform: translateY(0)`
3. Set `.popup` `padding: 24px`, `border-radius: 8px`, `max-width: 400px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Create a pop-up animation */
exercises.providedHtml:
Pop-up Title

This slides down and fades in.
hints: The hidden state uses opacity: 0 and transform: translateY(-30px) to be invisible and above
The visible state uses opacity: 1 and transform: translateY(0) for full visibility at normal position
transition on both properties creates a smooth slide-and-fade effect

exercises.title: Dropdown Menu Animation
exercises.description: Create a dropdown menu with a bounce animation using @keyframes. Based on The Odin Project.
exercises.instructions:
Build a dropdown menu that expands downward with a bounce effect.

1. Set `.dropdown` to `transform-origin: top` — makes it expand from the top
2. Set `.dropdown` `animation: dropDown 0.4s ease forwards`
3. Set `.dropdown` `padding: 8px 0` and `border-radius: 0 0 8px 8px`
4. Define `@keyframes dropDown`:
   - `0%`: `transform: scaleY(0)`, `opacity: 0`
   - `80%`: `transform: scaleY(1.05)` (slight overshoot for bounce)
   - `100%`: `transform: scaleY(1)`, `opacity: 1`
5. Set `.dropdown-item` `padding: 8px 16px`
exercises.starterCode: /* Create a bouncing dropdown animation */
exercises.providedHtml:
Option 1
Option 2
Option 3
hints: transform-origin: top makes scaleY expand downward from the top edge
@keyframes define animation steps: 0% (start), 80% (overshoot), 100% (end)
The bounce comes from scaleY(1.05) at 80% — slightly larger than final, then settling

exercises.title: Hero Name
exercises.description: Every hero needs a title. Combine a first name and a title into a proper hero name.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `heroName` that takes two parameters: `first` (a string) and `title` (a string). Return the string in the format `"[first] the [title]"`.

Example:
  heroName("Thorin", "Brave")  →  "Thorin the Brave"
  heroName("Elara", "Wise")   →  "Elara the Wise"
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return heroName;')(); return [ { pass: fn('Thorin', 'Brave') === 'Thorin the Brave', description: 'heroName("Thorin", "Brave") → "Thorin the Brave"', got: fn('Thorin', 'Brave') }, { pass: fn('Elara', 'Wise') === 'Elara the Wise', description: 'heroName("Elara", "Wise") → "Elara the Wise"', got: fn('Elara', 'Wise') }, { pass: fn('Kael', 'Undying') === 'Kael the Undying', description: 'heroName("Kael", "Undying") → "Kael the Undying"', got: fn('Kael', 'Undying') } ]; }
hints: You need to combine three strings: the first name, the word " the ", and the title.
Use the + operator to concatenate (join) strings together.
Make sure to include spaces around the word "the".

resources.label: MDN: String concatenation
resources.description: Combining strings with + or template literals

exercises.title: Weapon Damage
exercises.description: Calculate a weapon's total damage from its base power and a modifier, but damage can never go below zero.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `weaponDamage` that takes `base` (a number) and `modifier` (a number, can be negative). Return the total damage (`base + modifier`), but it should never be less than `0`.

Example:
  weaponDamage(10, 5)   →  15
  weaponDamage(10, -3)  →  7
  weaponDamage(3, -10)  →  0
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return weaponDamage;')(); return [ { pass: fn(10, 5) === 15, description: 'weaponDamage(10, 5) → 15', got: fn(10, 5) }, { pass: fn(10, -3) === 7, description: 'weaponDamage(10, -3) → 7', got: fn(10, -3) }, { pass: fn(3, -10) === 0, description: 'weaponDamage(3, -10) → 0 (never below zero)', got: fn(3, -10) }, { pass: fn(0, 0) === 0, description: 'weaponDamage(0, 0) → 0', got: fn(0, 0) } ]; }
hints: First add base and modifier together to get the raw damage.
Math.max(a, b) returns whichever value is larger. How can you use this to enforce a minimum of 0?
Math.max(0, base + modifier) ensures the result is never negative.

resources.label: MDN: Math.max()
resources.description: Returns the largest of the given numbers

exercises.title: Is It Magic?
exercises.description: Determine whether a weapon is magical based on its name.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `classifyWeapon` that takes a `name` string and returns `"magic"` if the name contains the word "Enchanted" or "Arcane"` (case-sensitive), otherwise returns `"mundane"`.

Example:
  classifyWeapon("Enchanted Sword")  →  "magic"
  classifyWeapon("Iron Axe")         →  "mundane"
  classifyWeapon("Arcane Staff")     →  "magic"
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return classifyWeapon;')(); return [ { pass: fn('Enchanted Sword') === 'magic', description: 'classifyWeapon("Enchanted Sword") → "magic"', got: fn('Enchanted Sword') }, { pass: fn('Iron Axe') === 'mundane', description: 'classifyWeapon("Iron Axe") → "mundane"', got: fn('Iron Axe') }, { pass: fn('Arcane Staff') === 'magic', description: 'classifyWeapon("Arcane Staff") → "magic"', got: fn('Arcane Staff') }, { pass: fn('Wooden Shield') === 'mundane', description: 'classifyWeapon("Wooden Shield") → "mundane"', got: fn('Wooden Shield') } ]; }
hints: The String.includes() method checks if a string contains a specific substring.
You need to check for two keywords: "Enchanted" and "Arcane". Use the || (or) operator.
Remember: includes() is case-sensitive, so "enchanted" would NOT match "Enchanted".

resources.label: MDN: String.includes()
resources.description: Check if a string contains a substring

exercises.title: Potion Strength
exercises.description: Rate a healing potion based on how many hit points it restores.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `potionStrength` that takes `hp` (a number) and returns a rating string:
- `hp` < 10 → `"weak"`
- `hp` < 30 → `"moderate"`
- `hp` < 60 → `"strong"`
- `hp` >= 60 → `"legendary"`

Example:
  potionStrength(5)   →  "weak"
  potionStrength(25)  →  "moderate"
  potionStrength(50)  →  "strong"
  potionStrength(100) →  "legendary"
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return potionStrength;')(); return [ { pass: fn(5) === 'weak', description: 'potionStrength(5) → "weak"', got: fn(5) }, { pass: fn(9) === 'weak', description: 'potionStrength(9) → "weak"', got: fn(9) }, { pass: fn(10) === 'moderate', description: 'potionStrength(10) → "moderate" (boundary)', got: fn(10) }, { pass: fn(25) === 'moderate', description: 'potionStrength(25) → "moderate"', got: fn(25) }, { pass: fn(50) === 'strong', description: 'potionStrength(50) → "strong"', got: fn(50) }, { pass: fn(100) === 'legendary', description: 'potionStrength(100) → "legendary"', got: fn(100) } ]; }
hints: Use a chain of if/else if statements, checking from smallest to largest.
Order matters: check hp < 10 first, then hp < 30, then hp < 60. If none match, it's legendary.
Each condition naturally excludes the previous ones when checked in order.

exercises.title: Gold Purse
exercises.description: Spend gold at the shop by looping through a list of prices.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `goldAfterShop` that takes `gold` (a number) and `prices` (an array of numbers). Loop through the prices, subtracting each from your gold. If you can't afford an item, skip it. Return the gold remaining.

Example:
  goldAfterShop(50, [10, 20, 5])   →  15
  goldAfterShop(20, [10, 15, 5])   →  5  (can't afford 15 after buying 10)
  goldAfterShop(5, [10, 20])       →  5  (can't afford anything)
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return goldAfterShop;')(); return [ { pass: fn(50, [10, 20, 5]) === 15, description: 'goldAfterShop(50, [10, 20, 5]) → 15', got: fn(50, [10, 20, 5]) }, { pass: fn(20, [10, 15, 5]) === 5, description: 'goldAfterShop(20, [10, 15, 5]) → 5', got: fn(20, [10, 15, 5]) }, { pass: fn(5, [10, 20]) === 5, description: 'goldAfterShop(5, [10, 20]) → 5 (can\'t afford anything)', got: fn(5, [10, 20]) }, { pass: fn(100, []) === 100, description: 'goldAfterShop(100, []) → 100 (empty shop)', got: fn(100, []) } ]; }
hints: Use a for loop to go through each price in the prices array.
Inside the loop, check if your gold is greater than or equal to the price before subtracting.
gold -= prices[i] is shorthand for gold = gold - prices[i].

resources.label: MDN: for loop
resources.description: Repeat code with a counting loop

exercises.title: Tavern Menu
exercises.description: Look up a meal's price from the tavern menu object.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `tavernOrder` that takes `menu` (an object where keys are item names and values are prices) and `item` (a string). Return the price of the item. If the item is not on the menu, return `"Not available"`.

Example:
  tavernOrder({ale: 2, stew: 5, bread: 1}, "stew")   →  5
  tavernOrder({ale: 2, stew: 5, bread: 1}, "wine")   →  "Not available"
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return tavernOrder;')(); const menu = {ale: 2, stew: 5, bread: 1, roast: 8}; return [ { pass: fn(menu, 'stew') === 5, description: 'tavernOrder(menu, "stew") → 5', got: fn(menu, 'stew') }, { pass: fn(menu, 'ale') === 2, description: 'tavernOrder(menu, "ale") → 2', got: fn(menu, 'ale') }, { pass: fn(menu, 'wine') === 'Not available', description: 'tavernOrder(menu, "wine") → "Not available"', got: fn(menu, 'wine') }, { pass: fn({}, 'stew') === 'Not available', description: 'tavernOrder({}, "stew") → "Not available" (empty menu)', got: fn({}, 'stew') } ]; }
hints: Access an object property with bracket notation: menu[item].
If a property doesn't exist on an object, accessing it returns undefined.
Check if menu[item] is undefined to decide whether to return the price or "Not available".

exercises.title: Health Bar (Basic)
exercises.description: Build a basic RPG health bar using CSS width percentages and background colors.
exercises.instructions:
Style a health bar where the outer container shows the track and the inner element shows current health.

1. `.health-bar` — the outer track:

2. `.health-fill` — the green fill inside:

exercises.title: Adventurer Title Card
exercises.description: Style a dark fantasy title card with a gold border for your adventurer.
exercises.instructions:
Style an adventurer's title card with a dark theme and gold accent.

1. `.title-card`:
   - `background-color: #0f172a` (very dark blue)
   - `border: 2px solid #d97706` (amber/gold)
   - `border-radius: 8px`
   - `padding: 16px`
   - `color: #f8fafc` (near white)
   - `text-align: center`
   - `max-width: 240px`

2. `.card-name`:
   - `font-size: 20px`
   - `color: #d97706` (gold, matching border)

3. `.card-class`:
   - `font-size: 14px`
   - `color: #94a3b8` (slate grey)
exercises.starterCode: /* Style the adventurer title card */
exercises.providedHtml:
Thorin the Brave
Warrior • Level 5
hints: Use background-color for the dark backdrop and border for the gold outline.
The gold color #d97706 is used on both the border and the .card-name text.
text-align: center on the parent card centers all text inside it.

resources.label: MDN: border
resources.description: Setting border width, style, and color

exercises.title: Repeat Battle Cry
exercises.description: Repeat a warrior's battle cry a given number of times using a loop.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `battleCry` that takes `word` (a string) and `times` (a number). Return the word repeated `times` times, separated by spaces.

Example:
  battleCry("Charge", 3)   →  "Charge Charge Charge"
  battleCry("Attack", 1)   →  "Attack"
  battleCry("Huzzah", 2)   →  "Huzzah Huzzah"
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return battleCry;')(); return [ { pass: fn('Charge', 3) === 'Charge Charge Charge', description: 'battleCry("Charge", 3) → "Charge Charge Charge"', got: fn('Charge', 3) }, { pass: fn('Attack', 1) === 'Attack', description: 'battleCry("Attack", 1) → "Attack"', got: fn('Attack', 1) }, { pass: fn('Huzzah', 2) === 'Huzzah Huzzah', description: 'battleCry("Huzzah", 2) → "Huzzah Huzzah"', got: fn('Huzzah', 2) }, { pass: fn('For Glory', 4) === 'For Glory For Glory For Glory For Glory', description: 'battleCry("For Glory", 4) repeats 4 times', got: fn('For Glory', 4) } ]; }
hints: Start with an empty string and build it up inside a loop.
You need to add a space between words, but not before the first one.
Check if i > 0 before adding a space, then always add the word.

resources.label: MDN: for loop
resources.description: Repeat code with a counting loop

resources.label: MDN: String concatenation
resources.description: Combining strings with + or template literals

exercises.title: Party Roll Call
exercises.description: Use .map() to create a roll call from an array of party member objects.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `rollCall` that takes `party` (an array of objects, each with `name` and `role` properties). Use `.map()` to return a new array of strings in the format `"[name] - [role]"`.

Example:
  rollCall([{name: 'Thorin', role: 'Warrior'}, {name: 'Elara', role: 'Mage'}])
  →  ["Thorin - Warrior", "Elara - Mage"]
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return rollCall;')(); const p1 = [{name:'Thorin',role:'Warrior'},{name:'Elara',role:'Mage'}]; const p2 = [{name:'Kael',role:'Rogue'},{name:'Lyra',role:'Cleric'},{name:'Dorn',role:'Paladin'}]; const r1 = fn(p1); const r2 = fn(p2); return [ { pass: JSON.stringify(r1) === JSON.stringify(['Thorin - Warrior','Elara - Mage']), description: 'Maps 2-member party to roll call strings', got: JSON.stringify(r1) }, { pass: r2.length === 3, description: '3-member party returns 3 strings', got: r2.length }, { pass: r2[2] === 'Dorn - Paladin', description: 'Third member is "Dorn - Paladin"', got: r2[2] }, { pass: JSON.stringify(fn([])) === '[]', description: 'Empty party returns empty array', got: JSON.stringify(fn([])) } ]; }
hints: .map() creates a new array by transforming each element with a callback function.
Each element in the party array is an object with .name and .role properties.
Return member.name + ' - ' + member.role inside the .map() callback.

resources.label: MDN: Array.map()
resources.description: Transform each element in an array

exercises.title: Loot Filter
exercises.description: Filter a loot pile to keep only items worth at least a minimum gold value.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `filterLoot` that takes `items` (an array of objects with `name` and `value` properties) and `minValue` (a number). Use `.filter()` to return only items whose `value` is greater than or equal to `minValue`.

Example:
  filterLoot([{name: 'Gem', value: 50}, {name: 'Rock', value: 1}, {name: 'Ring', value: 30}], 20)
  →  [{name: 'Gem', value: 50}, {name: 'Ring', value: 30}]
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return filterLoot;')(); const loot = [{name:'Gem',value:50},{name:'Rock',value:1},{name:'Ring',value:30},{name:'Coin',value:10}]; const r1 = fn(loot, 20); const r2 = fn(loot, 50); const r3 = fn(loot, 0); return [ { pass: r1.length === 2 && r1[0].name === 'Gem' && r1[1].name === 'Ring', description: 'Filters items worth >= 20: Gem and Ring', got: JSON.stringify(r1.map(i=>i.name)) }, { pass: r2.length === 1 && r2[0].name === 'Gem', description: 'Filters items worth >= 50: only Gem', got: JSON.stringify(r2.map(i=>i.name)) }, { pass: r3.length === 4, description: 'minValue 0 keeps all items', got: r3.length }, { pass: fn([], 10).length === 0, description: 'Empty loot returns empty array', got: fn([], 10).length } ]; }
hints: .filter() creates a new array containing only elements that pass a test.
The callback should return true when item.value >= minValue.
Remember: filter returns a new array, it doesn't modify the original.

resources.label: MDN: Array.filter()
resources.description: Keep elements that pass a test

exercises.title: Stat Block
exercises.description: Build a character stat block and find the strongest attribute.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `statBlock` that takes four numbers: `str`, `dex`, `int`, `wis`. Return an object with:
- `stats`: an object with properties `STR`, `DEX`, `INT`, `WIS` holding the values
- `strongest`: the name of the highest stat (e.g. `"STR"`). If there's a tie, return the first one alphabetically.

Example:
  statBlock(14, 10, 16, 12)
  →  { stats: { STR: 14, DEX: 10, INT: 16, WIS: 12 }, strongest: "INT" }
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return statBlock;')(); const r1 = fn(14,10,16,12); const r2 = fn(10,10,10,10); const r3 = fn(18,12,8,14); return [ { pass: r1.stats.STR === 14 && r1.stats.DEX === 10 && r1.stats.INT === 16 && r1.stats.WIS === 12, description: 'stats object has correct values', got: JSON.stringify(r1.stats) }, { pass: r1.strongest === 'INT', description: 'strongest is "INT" when INT is highest', got: r1.strongest }, { pass: r2.strongest === 'DEX', description: 'Tie: returns first alphabetically ("DEX")', got: r2.strongest }, { pass: r3.strongest === 'STR', description: 'strongest is "STR" when STR is highest', got: r3.strongest } ]; }
hints: Create an object with keys STR, DEX, INT, WIS and the provided values.
Loop through the object keys with a for...in loop to find the highest value.
For tie-breaking alphabetically, compare the key strings with < (string comparison).

exercises.title: Health Bar (Dynamic)
exercises.description: Create an animated health bar that transitions its width and color, with a hover effect to show full health.
exercises.instructions:
Build on the basic health bar with animations and a hover effect.

1. `.health-bar`:
   - `width: 240px`, `height: 28px`
   - `background-color: #1e293b`
   - `border-radius: 6px`
   - `overflow: hidden`

2. `.health-fill`:
   - `width: 40%` (low health)
   - `height: 100%`
   - `background-color: #ef4444` (red for low HP)
   - `border-radius: 6px`
   - `transition: width 0.5s ease, background-color 0.5s ease`

3. `.health-bar:hover .health-fill`:
   - `width: 100%`
   - `background-color: #22c55e` (green for full HP)
exercises.starterCode: /* Animated health bar with hover */
hints: The transition shorthand lets you animate multiple properties: transition: width 0.5s ease, background-color 0.5s ease
Use the descendant hover pattern: .health-bar:hover .health-fill targets the fill when the bar is hovered.
The fill starts red (low HP) and transitions to green (full HP) on hover, simulating healing.

exercises.title: Treasure Chest Counter
exercises.description: Count how many of each treasure type is in a loot array.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `countTreasure` that takes `loot` (an array of strings) and returns an object where each key is a loot type and each value is its count.

Example:
  countTreasure(["gold", "gem", "gold", "potion", "gold", "gem"])
  →  { gold: 3, gem: 2, potion: 1 }
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return countTreasure;')(); const r1 = fn(['gold','gem','gold','potion','gold','gem']); const r2 = fn(['sword']); const r3 = fn([]); return [ { pass: r1.gold === 3 && r1.gem === 2 && r1.potion === 1, description: 'Counts gold:3, gem:2, potion:1', got: JSON.stringify(r1) }, { pass: Object.keys(r1).length === 3, description: 'Result has exactly 3 keys', got: Object.keys(r1).length }, { pass: r2.sword === 1, description: 'Single item: sword:1', got: JSON.stringify(r2) }, { pass: Object.keys(r3).length === 0, description: 'Empty loot returns empty object', got: JSON.stringify(r3) } ]; }
hints: Create an empty object to store counts, then loop through the array.
For each item, check if it already exists in the object. If so, increment; if not, set to 1.
The pattern counts[item] = (counts[item] || 0) + 1 handles both cases in one line.

exercises.title: Damage Calculator
exercises.description: Calculate elemental combat damage with bonus multipliers for opposing elements.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `calcDamage` that takes `baseDamage` (number), `attackElement` (string), and `defenseElement` (string). Apply these elemental rules:
- Fire beats Ice (double damage)
- Ice beats Lightning (double damage)
- Lightning beats Fire (double damage)
- Same element: half damage
- All other combinations: normal damage

Return the final damage as a whole number (use `Math.floor`).

Example:
  calcDamage(20, "fire", "ice")        →  40  (fire beats ice)
  calcDamage(20, "fire", "fire")       →  10  (same element)
  calcDamage(20, "fire", "lightning")   →  20  (neutral)
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return calcDamage;')(); return [ { pass: fn(20, 'fire', 'ice') === 40, description: 'Fire vs Ice: 20 → 40 (double)', got: fn(20, 'fire', 'ice') }, { pass: fn(20, 'ice', 'lightning') === 40, description: 'Ice vs Lightning: 20 → 40 (double)', got: fn(20, 'ice', 'lightning') }, { pass: fn(20, 'lightning', 'fire') === 40, description: 'Lightning vs Fire: 20 → 40 (double)', got: fn(20, 'lightning', 'fire') }, { pass: fn(20, 'fire', 'fire') === 10, description: 'Fire vs Fire: 20 → 10 (half)', got: fn(20, 'fire', 'fire') }, { pass: fn(20, 'fire', 'lightning') === 20, description: 'Fire vs Lightning: 20 → 20 (neutral)', got: fn(20, 'fire', 'lightning') }, { pass: fn(15, 'ice', 'ice') === 7, description: 'Ice vs Ice: 15 → 7 (half, floored)', got: fn(15, 'ice', 'ice') } ]; }
hints: Check for the same-element case first — if attack and defense match, halve the damage.
Use an object to map each element to the element it beats: { fire: 'ice', ice: 'lightning', lightning: 'fire' }.
If the attacked element is the one your attack beats, double; otherwise return normal damage.

exercises.title: Stat Card
exercises.description: Build a character stat card using flexbox to display four RPG stats in a row.
exercises.instructions:
Build a character stat card with a row of RPG stats using flexbox.

**Required HTML:**
- A `.stat-card` container
- Inside: an `<h2>` with class `hero-name` containing any hero name
- A `.stats-row` div containing exactly 4 `.stat` divs
- Each `.stat` has a `.stat-value` (the number) and `.stat-label` (e.g. STR, DEX, INT, WIS)

**Required CSS:**
1. `.stat-card`: `background-color: #0f172a`, `border: 2px solid #d97706`, `border-radius: 8px`, `padding: 16px`, `max-width: 320px`, `color: #f8fafc`
2. `.stats-row`: `display: flex`, `justify-content: space-around`
3. `.stat`: `text-align: center`
4. `.stat-value`: `font-size: 24px`, `color: #d97706`
5. `.stat-label`: `font-size: 12px`, `color: #94a3b8`
exercises.solution:
Thorin the Brave

16
STR
12
DEX
8
INT
14
WIS
hints: Build the HTML structure first: a card with a hero name, then a row of 4 stat items.
Each stat item has two children: a .stat-value for the number and a .stat-label for the abbreviation.
Flexbox with justify-content: space-around evenly distributes the 4 stats with spacing.

exercises.title: Sort the Armory
exercises.description: Sort weapons by damage (highest first), breaking ties by weight (lightest first).
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `sortArmory` that takes `weapons` (an array of objects with `name`, `damage`, and `weight` properties). Sort them by `damage` descending. If two weapons have the same damage, sort by `weight` ascending (lighter first). Return the sorted array.

Example:
  sortArmory([
    {name: 'Dagger', damage: 5, weight: 1},
    {name: 'Sword', damage: 10, weight: 5},
    {name: 'Mace', damage: 10, weight: 8}
  ])
  →  [{name:'Sword',damage:10,weight:5}, {name:'Mace',damage:10,weight:8}, {name:'Dagger',damage:5,weight:1}]
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return sortArmory;')(); const w = [{name:'Dagger',damage:5,weight:1},{name:'Sword',damage:10,weight:5},{name:'Mace',damage:10,weight:8},{name:'Staff',damage:7,weight:3}]; const r = fn(w); return [ { pass: r[0].name === 'Sword', description: 'First: Sword (damage 10, weight 5)', got: r[0].name }, { pass: r[1].name === 'Mace', description: 'Second: Mace (damage 10, weight 8 — heavier)', got: r[1].name }, { pass: r[2].name === 'Staff', description: 'Third: Staff (damage 7)', got: r[2].name }, { pass: r[3].name === 'Dagger', description: 'Last: Dagger (damage 5)', got: r[3].name } ]; }
hints: Array.sort() takes a comparator function. Return negative to sort a before b, positive for b before a.
For descending damage: b.damage - a.damage. This puts higher damage first.
If damage is equal, use a.weight - b.weight as a tiebreaker (lighter first).

resources.label: MDN: Array.sort()
resources.description: Sort array elements with a custom comparator

exercises.title: XP to Level
exercises.description: Calculate how many levels a character gains from their XP, where each level costs more than the last.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `xpToLevel` that takes `xp` (a number). Each level costs `level × 100` XP to earn (level 1 costs 100, level 2 costs 200, level 3 costs 300, etc.). Start at level 0 and keep leveling up as long as you have enough XP. Return the final level.

Example:
  xpToLevel(100)   →  1  (100 XP buys level 1)
  xpToLevel(350)   →  2  (100 for lvl 1 + 200 for lvl 2 = 300 spent, 50 left)
  xpToLevel(0)     →  0
  xpToLevel(600)   →  3  (100+200+300 = 600 exactly)
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return xpToLevel;')(); return [ { pass: fn(100) === 1, description: 'xpToLevel(100) → 1', got: fn(100) }, { pass: fn(350) === 2, description: 'xpToLevel(350) → 2 (100+200=300, 50 left over)', got: fn(350) }, { pass: fn(0) === 0, description: 'xpToLevel(0) → 0', got: fn(0) }, { pass: fn(600) === 3, description: 'xpToLevel(600) → 3 (100+200+300=600)', got: fn(600) }, { pass: fn(99) === 0, description: 'xpToLevel(99) → 0 (not enough for level 1)', got: fn(99) }, { pass: fn(1000) === 4, description: 'xpToLevel(1000) → 4 (100+200+300+400=1000)', got: fn(1000) } ]; }
hints: Use a while loop that keeps running as long as you have enough XP for the next level.
The cost of the next level is (currentLevel + 1) * 100.
Subtract the cost from xp each time you level up, then increment the level.

resources.label: MDN: while loop
resources.description: Loop while a condition is true

exercises.title: Guild Roster
exercises.description: Group guild members by their role using .reduce().
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return guildRoster;')(); const m = [{name:'Thorin',role:'Warrior'},{name:'Elara',role:'Mage'},{name:'Kael',role:'Warrior'},{name:'Lyra',role:'Mage'},{name:'Dorn',role:'Cleric'}]; const r = fn(m); return [ { pass: JSON.stringify(r.Warrior) === JSON.stringify(['Thorin','Kael']), description: 'Warrior: ["Thorin", "Kael"]', got: JSON.stringify(r.Warrior) }, { pass: JSON.stringify(r.Mage) === JSON.stringify(['Elara','Lyra']), description: 'Mage: ["Elara", "Lyra"]', got: JSON.stringify(r.Mage) }, { pass: JSON.stringify(r.Cleric) === JSON.stringify(['Dorn']), description: 'Cleric: ["Dorn"]', got: JSON.stringify(r.Cleric) }, { pass: Object.keys(r).length === 3, description: 'Result has 3 role groups', got: Object.keys(r).length } ]; }
hints: .reduce() accumulates a single value by processing each array element. Start with an empty object {}.
For each member, check if roster[member.role] exists. If not, create it as an empty array.
Push member.name into roster[member.role], then return the roster for the next iteration.

exercises.title: Dungeon Key
exercises.description: Parse a dungeon row string and count how many of each tile type appears.
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return dungeonKey;')(); const r1 = fn('#.PG.M.#'); const r2 = fn('##DDD##'); const r3 = fn('....'); return [ { pass: r1['#'] === 2 && r1['.'] === 3 && r1['P'] === 1 && r1['G'] === 1 && r1['M'] === 1, description: '"#.PG.M.#" → #:2, .:3, P:1, G:1, M:1', got: JSON.stringify(r1) }, { pass: r2['#'] === 4 && r2['D'] === 3, description: '"##DDD##" → #:4, D:3', got: JSON.stringify(r2) }, { pass: r3['.'] === 4 && Object.keys(r3).length === 1, description: '"...." → only floor tiles', got: JSON.stringify(r3) }, { pass: Object.keys(fn('')).length === 0, description: 'Empty string returns empty object', got: JSON.stringify(fn('')) } ]; }
hints: Strings are iterable: you can use a for...of loop to go through each character.
Use the same frequency counting pattern as the Treasure Chest Counter exercise.
counts[ch] = (counts[ch] || 0) + 1 increments the count for each character.

exercises.title: Forge an Item
exercises.description: Create an Item class with methods to describe the item and check its category.
exercises.instructions:
Create a class called `Item` with:
- Constructor takes `name` (string), `type` (string: "weapon", "armor", "potion", or "scroll"), and `power` (number)
- `describe()` method returns `"[name] ([type]) - power: [power]"`
- `isWeapon()` returns true if type is `"weapon"`
- `isConsumable()` returns true if type is `"potion"` or `"scroll"`

Example:
  const sword = new Item("Iron Sword", "weapon", 12);
  sword.describe()      →  "Iron Sword (weapon) - power: 12"
  sword.isWeapon()      →  true
  sword.isConsumable()  →  false
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const cls = new Function(code + '; return Item;')(); const sword = new cls('Iron Sword','weapon',12); const potion = new cls('Health Potion','potion',25); const scroll = new cls('Fire Scroll','scroll',30); const armor = new cls('Shield','armor',8); return [ { pass: sword.describe() === 'Iron Sword (weapon) - power: 12', description: 'sword.describe() returns formatted string', got: sword.describe() }, { pass: sword.isWeapon() === true, description: 'sword.isWeapon() → true', got: sword.isWeapon() }, { pass: sword.isConsumable() === false, description: 'sword.isConsumable() → false', got: sword.isConsumable() }, { pass: potion.isConsumable() === true, description: 'potion.isConsumable() → true', got: potion.isConsumable() }, { pass: scroll.isConsumable() === true, description: 'scroll.isConsumable() → true', got: scroll.isConsumable() }, { pass: armor.isWeapon() === false, description: 'armor.isWeapon() → false', got: armor.isWeapon() } ]; }
hints: In the constructor, assign parameters to this.name, this.type, and this.power.
Methods defined inside a class can access the instance with 'this'.
isConsumable() should check for both 'potion' and 'scroll' types using ||.

exercises.title: The Spellbook
exercises.description: Filter affordable spells and find the best one matching an enemy's weakness.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `bestSpell` that takes `spells` (array of objects with `name`, `element`, `damage`, `manaCost`), `mana` (number), and `enemyWeakness` (string). Do two things:
1. Filter to only spells the caster can afford (manaCost <= mana)
2. Among affordable spells, find the one that matches the `enemyWeakness` element with the highest damage. If no matching spell is affordable, return `null`.

Return the spell object (or null).

Example:
  bestSpell([
    {name:'Fireball', element:'fire', damage:30, manaCost:20},
    {name:'Ember', element:'fire', damage:10, manaCost:5},
    {name:'Blizzard', element:'ice', damage:25, manaCost:15}
  ], 20, 'fire')
  →  {name:'Fireball', element:'fire', damage:30, manaCost:20}
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return bestSpell;')(); const spells = [{name:'Fireball',element:'fire',damage:30,manaCost:20},{name:'Ember',element:'fire',damage:10,manaCost:5},{name:'Blizzard',element:'ice',damage:25,manaCost:15},{name:'Inferno',element:'fire',damage:50,manaCost:40}]; return [ { pass: fn(spells, 20, 'fire').name === 'Fireball', description: 'With 20 mana, best fire spell is Fireball', got: fn(spells, 20, 'fire')?.name }, { pass: fn(spells, 5, 'fire').name === 'Ember', description: 'With 5 mana, only Ember is affordable', got: fn(spells, 5, 'fire')?.name }, { pass: fn(spells, 50, 'fire').name === 'Inferno', description: 'With 50 mana, Inferno has highest fire damage', got: fn(spells, 50, 'fire')?.name }, { pass: fn(spells, 20, 'lightning') === null, description: 'No lightning spells → null', got: fn(spells, 20, 'lightning') }, { pass: fn(spells, 1, 'fire') === null, description: 'Can\'t afford any fire spells → null', got: fn(spells, 1, 'fire') } ]; }
hints: First, filter spells where manaCost <= mana to get affordable ones.
Then filter those affordable spells to ones matching the enemy's weakness element.
Finally, find the spell with the highest damage from the matching set. .reduce() works well here.

exercises.title: Dungeon Map: Row Renderer
exercises.description: Parse a dungeon row string into an array of tile objects using a legend.
exercises.instructions:
Write a function called `renderRow` that takes a `row` string. Each character maps to a tile type using this legend:
- `#` → `"wall"`
- `.` → `"floor"`
- `P` → `"player"`
- `G` → `"gold"`
- `M` → `"monster"`
- `D` → `"door"`
- anything else → `"unknown"`

Return an array of objects: `{ char, tile }`.

Example:
  renderRow("#.PG#")
  →  [
    { char: '#', tile: 'wall' },
    { char: '.', tile: 'floor' },
    { char: 'P', tile: 'player' },
    { char: 'G', tile: 'gold' },
    { char: '#', tile: 'wall' }
  ]
exercises.testRunner: (code) => { const fn = new Function(code + '; return renderRow;')(); const r1 = fn('#.PG#'); const r2 = fn('DMD'); return [ { pass: r1.length === 5, description: '"#.PG#" produces 5 tiles', got: r1.length }, { pass: r1[0].char === '#' && r1[0].tile === 'wall', description: 'First tile: {char:"#", tile:"wall"}', got: JSON.stringify(r1[0]) }, { pass: r1[2].char === 'P' && r1[2].tile === 'player', description: 'Player tile: {char:"P", tile:"player"}', got: JSON.stringify(r1[2]) }, { pass: r1[3].tile === 'gold', description: 'G maps to "gold"', got: r1[3].tile }, { pass: r2[0].tile === 'door' && r2[1].tile === 'monster', description: 'D=door, M=monster', got: JSON.stringify(r2.map(t=>t.tile)) }, { pass: fn('X')[0].tile === 'unknown', description: 'Unknown char maps to "unknown"', got: fn('X')[0].tile } ]; }
hints: Create a legend object mapping characters to tile names: { '#': 'wall', '.': 'floor', ... }.
Split the string into an array of characters with .split('').
Use .map() to transform each character into a { char, tile } object, looking up the tile in the legend.

resources.label: MDN: String.split()
resources.description: Split a string into an array
